FOREWORD 3 Foreword H.E. TUNG-LAÏ MARGUE Ambassador of the European Union to Sri Lanka and the Maldives The devastation of three decades of conflict added to the destruction caused by the 2004 tsunami leaving hundreds of thousands of Sri Lankans homeless. As a response, between 2006 and 2016, the European Union (EU) has supported more than 80,000 internally dis- placed people (IDPs) reconstruct their houses in North and East Sri Lanka. This has been funded by the generous tax contributions of European Union citizens and channelled through the Eu- ropean Commission’s regional facility for Asian countries called Aid to Uprooted People (AUP). I am pleased that this evaluation report will make important lessons learnt availa- ble on-line via the European Union’s Publications Office. The aim is to help future similar programmes build on learnings, better address the identified shortcomings and satisfy the curiosity of tax payers who seek to understand how their money is spent in the con- text of international development cooperation. This evaluation reminds us again of how important it is to conceive ‘housing’ interven- tions as processes involving people’s empowerment, something that is more than the mere reconstruction of ‘houses’ as ‘brick and mortar’ only. In the jargon of our pro- grammes, ‘housing’ reconstruction works best if complemented by an array of ‘flanking measures’ that help sustaining households’ livelihoods. Accordingly, the EU will have not only assisted in the reconstruction 20,000 houses (half in the East and half in the North) but also helped regularise the land tenure of at least 6,000 households, improved local capacity of villages to plan their development, trained beneficiaries to lead the recon- struction process of their houses under the Home Owner Driven (HOD) approach and provided grants for basic community infrastructure such as water wells, schools, health centres, community centres and tertiary roads. Housing reconstruction that tries to pro- mote a ‘habitat’ approach has been positively reported upon by beneficiaries, praised by independent evaluations, appreciated by Governments and, in Sri Lanka, it has grown into a model of successful conflict-sensitive international development cooperation. Based on three decades of successful implementation in Sri Lana since the international- ly acclaimed Million Houses Programme, the practice of assisted ‘Home Owner Driven’ (HOD) reconstruction will be continued. This evaluation recommendations include: giving even more voice to communities in the tough process of beneficiary selection; and allo- cating more funds to these ‘flanking measures’, for instance through not only training beneficiaries in cost-effective technologies but by taking it a step further and supporting the local production of construction materials and low-cost housing services. Promoting

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 4 entrepreneurial initiatives out of those accrued skills can contribute to the local economy and to self-reliance of the local construction supply chain. Also, advocating for house- types that better accommodate the specific needs such as incremental growth, can allow for substantial increases in the utility and value of houses over time. Capacity building on the life-cycle management of houses and of scarce environmental resources is a proven driver of savings and of long-term livelihood viability. In addition, financial literacy needs to be provided to beneficiaries to sensitise them about the risks of excessive indebted- ness. Accordingly, by investing a little more on ‘flanking measures’ it might be possible to build cheaper houses, more people could benefit from an improved construction supply chain and beneficiaries could benefit from additional developmental prospects. On behalf of the European Union Delegation to Sri Lanka and the Maldives, I would like to thank European Union citizens, the Sri Lankan beneficiaries for their exemplary contributions to leading their own house reconstruction, the Sri Lankan Government for its unconditional support, the implementing agencies: UN-Habitat, the Swiss Agency for Development Cooperation (SDC), Habitat for Humanity and World Vision; as well as our co-donors involving the governments of Switzerland and Australia.

ExECUTIVE SUMMARY 15 Executive Summary This report is structured in two parts, each covering an owner driven housing reconstruc- tion programme in Sri Lanka mainly funded by the European Union’s (EU) Aid to Uproot- ed People (AUP) regional facility ( 1 ): 1. Part I is the Final Evaluation of the Improving Living Conditions in Returnee Areas of Sri Lanka through Housing programme implemented from January 2013 until June 2015 (hereinafter called AUP-2012) implemented by UN-Habitat and SDC. It received EUR 11.8 million from the EU and a combined amount of EUR 5.86 from the Australian Government, through the Agency for International Development (Au- sAid) ( 2 ), and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC). It covered the northern districts of Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Mannar and the eastern district of Batticaloa. 2. Part II is the Baseline Study of the Homes not Houses: Building a Sustainable Future Together programme implemented since December 2015 and due to be completed by December 2018 (hereinafter referred to as AUP-2014) is being jointly implemented by Habitat for Humanity International and World Vision Lanka. AUP- 2014 benefits from an EU contribution of EUR 14 million and EUR 0.7 million in co-fi- nancing from Habitat for Humanity International (Nadacia). AUP-2014 focuses on Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu in the North and on Batticaloa in the East. Since 2005, the EU-funded housing programmes in Sri Lanka under the AUP regional facility have targeted war-displaced households to assist them rebuild permanent houses on their own lands. This was done through a combination individual sub-grants to households accompanied by technical assistance aimed at helping them manage the reconstruction process. Programme after programme, this approach to Home Owner Driven (HOD) reconstruction process (also termed Owner Driven Recon- struction—ODR) has increased its emphasis on the so-called ‘flanking measures’ (e.g. minor allocations to livelihood support ranging from securing land tenure, commu- nity infrastructure to skills training for community building). The evaluation team comprises Dr Reinhard Skinner (Team Leader and Sociologist/Hous- ing Expert), Mr Mario Martelli (Architect) and Dr Mano Kumarasuriyar (Urban Planner/ Architect). The field study was conducted during March and April 2016. All stages of the evaluation have been critically assessed by Mr Jaime Royo Olid (Architect) programme manager from the EU-Delegation to Sri Lanka. The methods adopted for the evaluation and study included documentary analysis , a household survey of 400 beneficiaries of the AUP-2012 and 300 potential bene- ficiaries of the AUP-2014, 11 focus group discussions, 20 semi-structured inter- ( 1 ) There were also a number of bi-lateral donor agencies and INGOs contributing to post-tsunami housing in Sri Lanka (e.g. JICA, GTZ, AusAID, SIDA, ICRC, IOM) ( 2 ) In 2013 the Agency for International Development (AusAID) ceased to be an executive agency and was incorporated into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT).

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 16 views, 19 case studies of households and 30 non-participant observations as an audit of the design and construction processes . The evaluation team concludes that the AUP-2012 programme has been successful. AUP-2014 had not started field implementation when the baseline study was being carried out so no conclusive judgement can yet be made at this stage. However, the programme design contains many features which are promising, including many of the recommendations made in the 2015 report on the mid-term evaluation of AUP-2012 carried out by this team. UN-Habitat and SDC have performed impressively on several fronts . The evaluation revealed that the AUP-2012 programme has had a significant and positive impact on 17,436 direct housing beneficiaries. From an outcomes perspective, according to the survey, 100% of AUP-2012 beneficiaries felt that the housing programme had im- proved their standard of living. 90% of beneficiaries also felt that their relation- ships with other community members had improved substantially as a result of the housing programme. This suggests that the programme has gone well beyond merely sheltering the homeless and has contributed to building cohesive communities. These are important achievements with respect to the EU’s objective to ultimately con- tribute to peace and reconciliation . From a perspective of outputs, the programme has delivered many more full house equivalents (FHEs) than originally contracted : AUP-2012 delivered 4,251 which is 10% more than the target. This improved level of output can be attributed to foreign exchange rate gains, savings on operations costs and increased beneficiary contributions. In agreement with the European Union Delegation (EUD) to Sri Lanka the evaluation report focuses on areas of work where improvements can be most usefully made. This is intended to provide guidance for forthcoming housing programmes, housing re- construction policy and development planning in rural Sri Lanka at large. For instance, with regards to the intended improvement in social cohesion, certain as- pects of the beneficiary selection process are strongly disputed not only by those not selected but also by many beneficiaries. They claim some criteria disregard prevalent cultural norms and values. The evaluators found this first during the mid-term evalua- tion in September 2014 and recommended in their report that the scoring system be reviewed with the participation of the target communities to improve its accept- ance and to improve a sense of fairness. While this came rather late in the AUP-2012 programme, and was not implemented, it was taken up in the design of the subsequent AUP-2014 programme. Some other problems which have been confirmed by our field mission and surveys and addressed in this report, such as dependency syndrome and indebtedness, have not been caused by the implementing partners – though they may be unintentional contributors – but have been largely brought about by the historical context in which livelihood and housing assistance have been provided for separately. The implementing partners have been required to work sectorally to deliver housing reconstruction as a

ExECUTIVE SUMMARY 17 complement to livelihood support programmes that most often involved different beneficiaries and locations. Though often adjacent, their complementarity has not al- ways materialised geographically. The housing types and construction standards are somewhat rigid and beneficiary expec- tations high as a result of two financially generous waves of post-emergency reconstruc- tion assistance (i.e. post-tsunami and post-war). Technical specifications and expectations have not been sufficiently adapted to changes such as prohibitive inflation of construc- tion costs (both labour and materials). Emerging developmental needs such as the need to ensure locally-sustained livelihood and income opportunities beyond reconstruction are becoming more pronounced and will need to be addressed in order for households to be viable in the long-term. Again, these are addressed in the design of the new AUP- 2014 programme. In trying to break away from assistance dependency syndrome among the beneficiary communities home owners have increasingly been required to provide in-kind contributions and unskilled labour. This has improved ownership of the housing process but has also tied them to the house construction often de- nying them the opportunity to work to cover day-to-day expenses. In Chapter Six, it is argued that the combination of dependency, lack of financial literacy and interruptions in income generation through the reconstruction process undermines the otherwise sat- isfactory sustainability of the programme. Allocating either, a full house, a repair, or nothing, translates into either, huge gains for beneficiaries or nothing for those left out. Towards achieving a broader spread of ben- efits, three alternatives and cheaper incremental housing designs were recommended in this mid-term evaluation. These are to be understood as indicative house types to be further adapted to local norms, regulations, and cultural sensitivities through owner-driv- en processes and not as blueprints. The designs proposed then were smaller than the current standard ( 1 ) full house equivalents (i.e. 550 sq. feet, lockable house with toilet, high-pitched roof) but are fully functional houses with potential for expansion. It was already recommended in the mid-term evaluation of AUP-2012 that an “incremen- tal housing” approach be introduced in future programmes in which lifecycle de- mands of house owners are anticipated. Providing completed houses, perhaps smaller than the current 550 sq. feet, but with clear potential for expansion could free up funds to include more beneficiaries and to provide more livelihood support and training activi- ties. Gradually phasing in non-exploitative loans through sound financial mechanisms cre- ating financial discipline among beneficiaries and other actions to mitigate dependency are presented in Chapters Five and Eleven. These mid-term evaluation recommendations have all been incorporated in the design of AUP-2014. Managing the above is important for housing reconstruction not to add to the gener- al tendency to get deeply indebted. Spending on the house far above what the AUP grant allowance must be proactively discouraged in order to sustain manageable levels of household debt. SDC’s study on indebtedness (Romeshun, K. V. EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 18 Munas, 2014) and housing documents the importance of debt for completing house reconstruction but underlines that no causality can be directly established between hous- ing reconstruction and unsustainable debt which is mainly caused by structural factors (e.g. exploitative credit lending to up to 30% interest rate taking advantage of lack of financial literacy, alcoholism, drought and flooding, etc..). This evaluation confirms that 93% of AUP-2012 beneficiaries borrowed to complete their construction and that in such circumstances 72% of them found debt was causing them problems. In order to address unsustainable indebtedness it was recommended in the mid-term eval- uation of AUP-2012 that future grants build in stronger livelihoods and training components. This was too late for the AUP-2012 programme to do but AUP-2014 has done so. A particular concern in the construction process is that, while the overall quality of the houses in both programmes implemented by UN-Habitat (AUP-2010 and AUP- 2012) has been generally good, the duration taken for completion is considered too long . The need for households and their family members to carry out seasonal work (e.g. fishing and farming) and other occasional priorities, together with a serious short- age of skilled labour and sometimes of construction materials in the districts, are the main causes. Proposals are made in Chapter Eight to reduce this time. Those two AUP programmes incorporated beneficiary financial and physical participation as well as community participation in the collective/bulk procurement of building materi- als through the specially created Village Reconstruction Committees (VRCs). However, the potential contribution of existing CBOs was found not to have been sufficiently exploited. The AUP-2014 should take this finding on board. In the mid-term evaluation the team looked at the visibility of the programme and con- cluded that, though some aspects are covered well enough, the then deliberate low-pro- file approach could be considered as falling short of donors’ expectations. This has since been improved. There remains over 100,000 very vulnerable households, who will struggle to ever afford a house and face a high risk of remaining in poverty. In our previous report and with regards to the donor’s exit strategy from a situation of donor-dependency in ad- dressing the post-war housing reconstruction gap, an abrupt disengagement was discouraged and the facilitation of a smooth transition to a local non-exploitative housing market encouraged. Since then, the Government has changed and housing has become again a central social and economic objective. The current Government is committed to delivering subsidised housing for both war victims in the North and East, for most vulnerable communities in Central and Uva provinces and concessionary loans countrywide. Amid these good intentions however, the tentative programme of 65,000 prefabricated houses which were to be built and imported by steel giant Arcelor Mittall at a cost of some USD 1 billion has raised many questions in various sectors. Civil society has alleged a lack of fair competition in procurement process and evaluation where the winner was

ExECUTIVE SUMMARY 19 said to have been pre-decided. But more importantly, given the availability of nation- al solutions, this shows a disappointing disjuncture between thirty years of successful owner-driven housing in Sri Lanka and the lack of appropriation of the same by the new Minister of Resettlement ( 1 ). The present report argues that, since no affordable market mechanism is yet in place, the housing reconstruction gap must continue to be addressed through public intervention and policy which builds on lessons learnt such as the AUPs. The EU and other experienced implementing partners are today in a privileged position to facilitate key capacity build- ing and knowledge transfer for a much needed ‘national housing policy’. While owner driven practices integrating livelihood support have become a best-practice there is still ample room for improvement such as by including incremental housing, non-exploitative finance, certified vocational training and the strengthening of CBOs. A Sri Lankan housing policy should include local value-added enterprise development in the North and the East that diversifies the construction supply chain and that provides for low-cost solutions. The extent to which the AUP-2014 programme, manages to illustrate the way forward will determine its success. PART I FINAL EVALUATION OF THE PROGRAMME Improving Living Conditions in Returnee Areas of Sri Lanka through Housing Programme funded by the EU’s Aid to Uprooted People (AUP) 2012 Implemented by UN-Habitat and the Swiss Agency for Development Cooperation Contract No DCI-ASIE/2012/296-666

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 22 1 Introduction Sri Lanka’s two decade long internal conflict, mainly in the north and the east of the country, coupled with the tsunami disaster of December 2004, which had the sever- est impact along the north-east and the eastern coastal belt of the country, left about 365,000 houses fully or partially damaged. The European Union’s support for the reconstruction of social infrastructure, livelihoods and damaged houses in the affected areas has involved over €674 million between the initial intervention in 2005 and 2015. In the first two AUP interventions in 2005 and 2006, a total of €16 million was committed to the World Bank-led North East Housing Reconstruction Programme (NEHRP). It was followed by a third AUP contribution of €12 million in 2008 towards emergency housing implemented by ASB in Vavuniya complemented by ZOA and Practical Action responsible for the so-called ‘flanking meas- ures’ components ( 1 ). ( 1 ) Flanking measures are small-scale supports to beneficiary communities in the areas of infrastructure and livelihoods.

INTRODUCTION 23 Figure 2: NEHRP permanent house next to transitional shelter, Ampara District, 2007 In 2010, as the internal conflict-related emergencies added on to the backlog of tsunami housing programmes, the EU responded through the AUP facility with a commitment of €12 million towards Support to Conflict Affected People through Housing Programme, implemented by UN-Habitat and SDC. It is referred to by the EUD as AUP-2010 and by UN-Habitat as Phase I. An additional €4 million was sourced through AusAID/DFAT and SDC (the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation). The global objective of AUP-2010 was “to contribute to a sustainable resettlement in the place of origin for the returnees and their host communities in North Sri Lanka” and its spe- cific objective “to improve the living conditions and social cohesion of displaced people, re- turnees and their host communities in the North through provision of permanent housing”. The AUP-2012 or UN-Habitat Phase II was a replication of the AUP-2010 programme im- plemented with the same partners – UN-Habitat, AusAID/DFAT and SDC, but adopting a theme of “Improving Living Conditions in Returnee Areas of Sri Lanka through Housing” by targeting 3,000 fully damaged houses for reconstruction and 1,000 repairs to those partially damaged. Its global objective was “to address medium term rehabilitation needs of returnees and their host communities in the North and East of Sri Lanka” and its specific objective “to improve the living conditions and social cohesion of displaced people, re- turnees and their host communities in the North and East through provision of permanent housing”. The funding breakdown among the partners remained similar to the AUP-2010 pro- gramme – EU providing €11.8 million and the combined AusAID (which later became DFAT)/SDC contribution being approximately €5.86 million. The programme aimed to reach 100 villages in the four targeted districts in the north – Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu and Mannar, as well as 1,000 households in the Batticaloa district in the east.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 24 1.2 The present evaluation By the end of the present evaluation in April 2016 the AUP-2010 and AUP-2012 pro- grammes had produced 7,028 completely new, rebuilt houses (“full houses” in the pro- gramme’s terminology) and 2,609 repaired houses. In addition there were other outputs such as community infrastructure, training and support in obtaining land titles (all of which are detailed in this report). Although the programmes have delivered substantial benefits, which are described in the present report, the EU’s intention through evaluation is to further improve ongoing programme performance for better and greater impact and to extract lessons learnt for future housing reconstruction actions. Figure 3: Completed house under AUP-2012, Eravurpattu Village, Batticaloa District (23 March 2016) When the present evaluation was commissioned in January 2014 the shortfall in housing in the north (houses destroyed during the war which needed to be reconstructed) was not openly known but estimated by UN-Habitat to be in the range of 30,000 – 60,000 with an additional 5,000 – 12,000 for the eastern Batticaloa District. The new Govern- ment under president Maitripala has reinstated housing as a priority and estimates the gap at above 100,000. Housing programmes would have to be scaled up significantly if this need is to be met. Accordingly, the new Government has committed itself to various housing schemes: grant-based for war-affected people and concessionary loans for other social housing. For war-affected people, the approaches diverge however: on the one hand a 10,000 owner-driven housing programme has been launched under the leadership of the districts building on lessons learnt from previous owner-driven pro- grammes. On the other, a 65,000 house project of prefabricated houses was awarded to international steel giant ArcelorMittal. The latter has caused dismay among potential beneficiaries, local contractors and the donor community ( 1 ). In addition, it was observed ( 1 ) The AUP beneficiaries felt that it was unfair that, while they were struggling to complete their houses within a budget of Rs.550,000, some new beneficiaries were to get houses and contents worth Rs.2.1 million. This was definitely going to cause a lot of friction between the two groups of beneficiaries if they happened live in the same village.

INTRODUCTION 25 or suspected that several problems were constraining home ownership or home improve- ment. These included landlessness, inflation in building materials and labour costs and political intervention in beneficiary selection. It is against this backdrop that the final evaluation of the AUP–2010 programme and mid- term evaluation of the AUP–2012 programme were undertaken. The report delivered at the end of the two evaluations, it was hoped, would contribute substantially in helping the AUP-2012 programme make modifications to improve on its already impressive per- formance and for future programmes to be designed and implemented to perform even better. In this way, they would be able to benefit the as yet unserved populations in the north and east of Sri Lanka. The present evaluation, led by IBF International Consulting, was carried out in March and April 2016 and comprises the final evaluation of AUP-2012 and baseline study of the new AUP-2014. The latter was designed taking into account many of the recommendations of the mid-term evaluation of AUP-2012. The global objective of the AUP-2012 final evaluation and baseline study is to: Empower key stakeholders involved in EU-funded housing reconstruction programmes in Sri Lanka with knowledge or skills identified through programme evaluations necessary to undertake well-informed decisions, corrective measures or complementary activities to better attain EU development cooperation objectives. (Evaluation TOR: 4) Specific objectives are to: 1. identify relevant areas for potential improvement as well as examples of good practice in the implementation and design of the programmes concerned; 2. disseminate the relevant findings in the form of practical and feasible recommenda- tions; 3. mainstream, to the relevant stakeholders, practical methods, skills or approaches to follow up on the recommendations. (loc. cit.). 1.3 The structure of the report The present report is in two parts: the first part covers the final evaluation of AUP-2012 and the second the baseline study of AUP-2014. METHODS 27 2 Methods The methodology employed in the final evaluation of AUP-2012 is very similar to that employed for the mid-term evaluation of the same programme. The method employed in the baseline study is different and is presented in the second part of this report. The following summarises the methods used in the AUP-2012 final evaluation. Evaluation criteria had been given in the evaluation’s Terms of Reference (ToR). These were relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, sustainability, impact, coherence and community value added . From these the evaluation team drew up evaluation questions and compiled them in the Evaluation Question Matrix, which appears in Annex 4. This shows the criteria, questions, likely sources of information and the most appropriate evaluation method to be employed to answer the questions. The ToR required that the evaluation be both qualitative and quantitative and that household surveys be carried out with each respondent’s house being photographed and geo-referenced. The other methods (documentary analysis, focus group discussions, semi-structured interviews and non-participant observation) were selected by the evalu- ation team. 2.1 Documentary Analysis The evaluation requires that the AUP programmes be evaluated at different levels ranging from the global (e.g. their contribution to national development) to the very specific (such as the timely payment of grant instalments). The best source for this data is existing doc- umentation. Strategy level documents provided the answers to the first type of question (e.g. the National Development Plan and the “Awakening the North” regional develop- ment strategy) while programme documents address the second. In addition the team has made use of a range of other materials such as the AUP Operations Manual, Annual and Final Report of AUP-2012 which ended on 30 June 2015, specific research studies (e.g. on indebtedness and vulnerability) as well as academic articles. 2.2 Household Survey A local survey team was sub-contracted to carry out a household survey. It carried out a total of 723 interviews with householders . These comprised 364 beneficiaries of the AUP-2012 programme (the final evaluation) and 259 potential beneficiaries of AUP-2014 (the baseline study). In addition, 50 interviews were carried out for each programme as pilot surveys. Those surveyed for the final evaluation of AUP-2012 were beneficiaries of a full house or repaired house. They were randomly selected from a database maintained by UN-Habi- tat. The method used for the selection of respondents for the AUP-2012 baseline study is explained in the corresponding section of the second part of this report.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 32 3 Beneficiary Selection System (AUP – 2012) As was highlighted in AUP-2012 Mid-term Evaluation Report (MTE), the selection of ben- eficiaries has played an important role in the successful progress of the implementation of AUP-2012. The AUP-2012, attempted to introduce objectivity in the selection process through a scoring system as adopted in the Indian Housing Project (IHP). Though intended to build in a level of transparency in the selections, the scoring system did not receive the expected levels of acceptance from the target community. Criticisms of the system were perhaps mainly due to the community at large, particularly those not selected, tending to feel aggrieved as every single person in the target groups, rightly, considers himself or herself to be an “uprooted person” at whom the AUPs were tar- geted ( 1 ). Apparently, the community considered the criteria and the relative weights assigned to each in the scoring system to be very subjective and unfair. Though well-in- tended, the scoring system had the tendency to discriminate against one of the most vulnerable such as those who had lost several members in the war, which reduced them to a small family who now may not be eligible for a house due to the scoring system’s bias towards larger families. However, despite the efforts of the implementing partners and all others concerned to ensure a high degree of fairness, transparency and accountability when selecting the beneficiaries, it was observed in the MTE report that a small but significant number of applicants had missed out being selected even though the general consensus was that that they should have. The bone of contention was that the selection criteria had been indifferent to certain local cultural norms and ground conditions. On the basis of this observation it was recommended in the MTE report that the selection criteria be re- viewed and revised appropriately. For example, selection criteria should take into account what communities considered appropriate criteria. Another example, proposed here by the evaluation team, is that criteria do not discriminate against households with female members who are over 18 and unemployed as was the case in the AUP-2012 beneficiary selection process. However, by the time the MTE was concluded and the report with rec- ommendations was released to the Implementing Partners all selections had been done, the houses constructed (except for a few) and were in occupation. It is now hoped that the beneficiary selection process for AUP-2014 would take due note of the AUP- 2012 MTE conclusions and recommendations. Despite the selection process formerly allowing for redress of grievances (UN-Habi- tat Operational Manual 2013-2015, p6), almost 40% of non-beneficiaries surveyed for the MTE had claimed that they were unaware of the reasons why their appli- cations were rejected and almost 60% felt that their disqualification was unfair. ( 1 ) In most of the focus groups the beneficiaries and non-beneficiaries understood why the non-beneficiaries had not been selected for a grant but also felt this was unfair. EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 34 4 Dependency The present chapter is largely as it appeared in the AUP-2012 mid-term evaluation report since the issues and conclusions remain the same. However, some updates are made using information gathered during the final evaluation mission in March and April 2016, especially in the section on recommendations at the end. Both the AUP programmes have adopted an approach which aims to place control in the hands of the home owner – the “Home Owner Driven” (HOD) approach also referred to in academic literature as “Owner Driven Reconstruction” (ODR). The mid-term evaluation of AUP-2012 pointed out that this has had notable success in the sense that most house plans have been adapted to a certain extent by the home owners and they have been responsible for organising their own construction process. They have also contributed to the construction themselves in kind and to the monetary costs through loans they have made where the AUP grant was not (considered) sufficient for the size of house they wanted. Lyons (2009, 395) has compared owner-driven and donor-assisted approaches to post-tsunami housing in Sri Lanka and concludes: The findings clearly demonstrate that the Owner-Driven Programme in Sri Lan- ka (ODP) performed better than the Donor Assisted Programme (DAP) on both quantitative and qualitative criteria (Cernea, 1997, 2000). The ODP produced more houses, more quickly, of better construction quality, and at less cost. Space standards were generally better, and the designs, layouts, and locations were more acceptable to beneficiaries. Infrastructure, services, and amenities were more readily provided to ODP sites. She explains that DAPs also produced dependency amongst beneficiaries: Far more than the ODP, the DAP fostered a culture of dependency among ben- eficiaries, arising from long periods in transitional shelters, often away from both original and final places of abode, with no active role for beneficiaries to play in the development of their own futures. In contrast, the ODP fostered (re) development of a cooperative local social fabric and institutions achieved only exceptionally in the DAP and, as a process, met a range of human rights needs generally neglected by DAP […]. It created opportunity for integrated develop- ment (Cernea, 1997, 2000), built on beneficiaries’ energies (Oliver-Smith, 1991) and enhanced resilience of individuals and communities (Schilderman, 2004). The AUP programmes have adopted the ODP approach and appear to have captured many of the benefits described by Lyons. Ironically though, it seems also to have rein- forced the dependency she found in the DAP approach which was adopted by some agencies in the post-tsunami housing programmes. The AUP programmes, except where they have been implemented by SDC, have not significantly fostered the redevelopment

DEPENDENCY 35 of a cooperative social fabric and institutions or created opportunities for integrated de- velopment and enhanced the resilience of individuals and communities. The UN-Habitat managed programmes have: (a) By-passed existing CBOs in favour of VRCs ( 1 ) which have no chance of being regis- tered and therefore representing an institutional future for communities’ develop- ment. The programmes have created a new organisation instead of strengthening the legitimacy of existing ones. However, it should be noted that during the final evaluation of AUP-2012 it some villagers expressed their intention to continue using the VRCs even after the end of the programme. This reflects a generally positive ap- preciation of the VRCs’ work during focus group discussions. The question remains that, if they do continue how far does their lack of official recognition restrict their future development role? (b) Implemented a Settlement Improvement Planning process by means of which prior- ities are listed but most remain unattended. Of course, AUP cannot meet all needs but communities are left with a list of priorities with which they do not know how to deal. A valuable planning process has been left incomplete. Focus groups told the evaluation team what the unmet needs were and were looking for external assistance to meet them. (c) Adopted a sectorial approach too focused on housing rather than an integrated approach which would better develop resilience within communities ( 2 ). This was brought home in almost all focus group discussions in the mid-term evaluation where participants were extremely pleased with their houses but were worried that they had little or no income to cover daily expenses let alone repay the debts many of them had incurred as part of the housing process. The time many beneficiaries had spent as IDPs in camps and transitional shelters no doubt contributed to a culture of dependency. Unfortunately, the design of the AUP programmes only exacerbated this through the granting of, by rural Sri Lanka stand- ards, enormous amounts of money to build or repair their houses. The decision by many beneficiaries to build their house design or specification beyond the minimum standard has driven many of them to take on debts they cannot repay (see Chapter Eight) and increased even further their likely future dependency ( 3 ). ( 1 ) Some of these were established under the NEHRP programme and UN-Habitat has simply continued to use them instead of other CBOs. ( 2 ) It should be said that this sectorial approach was a response to the requirements specified by the EU. The guidelines for grant applicants for AUP 2010 stated “The programme will seek to promote returns of populations to their place of origin by prioritising permanent housing, in addition to previous EU investments in reconstruction notably in the housing sector through the North East Housing Reconstruction Programme (NEHRP).” It goes on to state that whilst funding for flanking measures is not foreseen within this programme, strong coordination with other EU supported actions will be promoted. AUP 2012 continued this approach. The evaluators are grateful to UN-Habitat for pointing this out. Nor is it the case that there are no ‘flanking measures’ (e.g. community infrastructure) incorporated by the programme. The point is that these investments have been too small compared to those made in housing. ( 3 ) It has been said in this respect that this is the beneficiary’s choice (the peoples’ process is all about people making their own choices) which seems to the evaluators to be irresponsible.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 36 This dependency is reflected in the replies given by most of the focus groups to questions about who would maintain common assets such as improved internal roads or drainage channels. They expected UN-Habitat, the District or NGOs to do it ( 1 ). This was despite the fact that most of the communities in which the focus groups were held had CBOs, such as RDSs and WRDSs, which had carried out such activities as providing organised labour for the road improvements, digging drainage channels, setting up small savings and loan programmes and digging foundations for pre-schools including contributions to UN-Hab- itat implemented projects through community infrastructure projects ( 2 ). They have the potential to become a development force in their communities but this has probably not been developed within the AUP programmes as much they could have been. 4.1 Recommendations 1) AUP-2012 has included a component of CBO strengthening (leadership training) which until now has not yet created the self-confidence to enable communities to tackle their own needs ( 3 ). The MTE recommended that this component be continued and reinforced in any subsequent phase of AUP and the proposal for the AUP-2014 incudes a sub-programme specifically aimed at strengthening community organisa- tions and reducing the culture of dependency. Part of the strengthening of CBOs should consist of training in how to follow up on those aspects of the Settlement Improvement Plan (SIP) process that AUP cannot (and should not) attend. This would include the preparation of plans and identifying development partners ( 4 ). 2) The MTE recommended that incremental (yet fully functional) housing should be pro- moted. This would establish a development model in which it is clear that a major part of the responsibility for completion of the house is the home owner’s. AUP-2012 did not incorporate this recommendation after the mid-term evaluation. UN-Habitat say the reason for this is that the MTE report was finalised in February 2016 and the programme due to end five months later so there was insufficient time. In fact, the proposal was made during the first evaluation mission in September 2014, leaving a full nine months to implement changes. The evaluation team accepts that the official version of the recommendation did indeed arrive later but feels that some efforts could have been made nevertheless ( 5 ). ( 1 ) In Iranapallai, the first reply to this question was “the next NGO that comes along”. They then corrected themselves: “We are confident we can do it ourselves” followed by “I think that is the right answer”. Communities are aware of the large resources available from which they can benefit but are also savvy to what development agencies want to hear. ( 2 ) Community infrastructure contracts, signed directly with CBOs, require CBOs to contribute to construction, financial management and the contribution of organized labour. UN-Habitat provides training on finance and construction issues. This has happened in close to 100 community contracts implemented under Phases I and II. EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 38 5 Sustainability The present chapter is largely as it appeared in the AUP-2012 mid-term evaluation report since the issues and conclusions remain the same. However, some updates are made using information gathered during the final evaluation mission in March and April 2016 as well as from the programme’s Final Report which was published in May. Sustainability [in evaluation] is concerned with measuring whether the benefits of an activity are likely to continue after donor funding has been withdrawn . (DAC, 2008, parentheses added). In the AUP programmes the relevant benefits are their outputs, services and outcomes. The kind of sustainability envisaged is the maintenance of houses and community ser- vices as well as any improvements in community organisational capacity and social cohesion . Various researchers, consultants and practitioners have discussed the different dimen- sions of sustainability and how to achieve it (WASH, LinkedIn online, numerous discus- sants; Roberts & Williams, 2008). From this work we can identify five generic types or components of sustainability as follows: 1) Financial sustainability (attained through funding); 2) Institutional (the delivery of benefits is taken up by government as part of its policy, strategy, legal framework, procedures or training programme); 3) Environmental (natural resources are managed in such a way that, to the extent that they are needed for the delivery or maintenance of benefits, they will continue to be available and, in any case, will not be depleted to an extent that threatens their future existence); 4) Technical (the benefits are technically replicable when the programme ends; the tech- nology needed for the continued delivery of benefits is maintained, repaired and replaced); 5) Social (the benefits are valued by beneficiaries and are ‘owned’ by them); The following table shows how these types of sustainability apply to the AUP-2012 pro- gramme.

It was reported the AUP-2012 MTE that work on these strategic areas was weaker than it should be. One important overarching constraint on sustainability is the dependency of local communities (see Chapter Four). As long as this remains, a strong community role in guaranteeing sustainability is unlikely. The mid-term evaluators of AUP-2010 extended the analysis of sustainability into the issue of sustainable resettlement as such. They argue that this requires more than the delivery of houses: … if only houses are built in villages and other facilities are inadequate or un- available, the chances for a sustainable resettlement in the place of origin are certainly reduced. Therefore, sustainable resettlement will to a large extent depend on the success in coordinating and providing complementary infra- structure and services . [… ] the absence of an integrated process may result in a delayed or weakened socio-economic response and recovery by the commu- nity. Several villages were visited where limitations on resources, such as water and schools, strained the social fabric. (Meindertsma and Nixon, 2012: 55-56). The authors went on to tell of a village where some 100 families had left because of the lack of schools and drinking water. In almost all the focus group discussions in both the AUP-2012 MTE and the final eval- uation it was found that CBOs - in particular, the RDSs and WRDSs - had organised and carried out common activities to the benefit of the community. However, it was equally evident that they did not expect to maintain the benefits of the AUP programmes. ( 1 ) AUP-2014 incudes water as one of its areas of intervention though it seems to be mainly in the areas of irrigation and conservation than drinking water supply (HfH & WVL, 2015). Recommendations made by the MTE team: 1. Establish community – local government partnerships; 2. Increase the livelihoods development component in marketable and income generat- ing trades (not only those with a fixed life span, like construction); 3. Strengthen CBOs and emphasise community responsibility for the sustainability of programme benefits. UN-Habitat responded to the first and third of these by recruiting a Community Consoli- dation Specialist at the end of the project “to ensure the sustainability of the VRCs and link them with the relevant development partners at ground level” (UN-Habitat, 2016: 22). The final evaluation team was unaware of this welcome measure until the programme’s

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 42 final report was written in May 2016 so did not research it. The final report does not detail what the new Specialist would do. The recommendations were also taken up in the new AUP-2014 proposal which includes components which specifically address the second and third of these. It is unclear wheth- er the first recommendation will be incorporated ( 1 ). LIVELIHOODS AND TRAINING (AUP –2012) 43 6 Livelihoods and Training (AUP –2012) The AUP-2012, following on from its predecessor AUP-2010, had been implemented in the development mode rather than in the emergency recovery mode as was observed in the MTE report. This being so, while the provision of shelters for the homeless refu- gees was a priority of the programmes, it was also critical that the housing programmes were sustainable. Towards this end, it was felt that beneficiary households should be provided with adequate income earning opportunities to be able to afford the difference between the AUP grant (Rs.550,000) and the actual cost of construction, which tended to be higher than the grant. Long gone are the emergency circumstances under which quick-fix solutions were sought to address basic needs of the affected population. In the development mode, while addressing a basic need, its sustainability has also got to be considered (see also Chapter Five on Sustainability). It is in this context that this evaluation has considered livelihood and training programmes available to, and taken up by, the beneficiaries to be essential elements of the AUP programmes. The findings of the study in this respect are presented below. 6.1 Starting Life from Scratch Most uprooted people appear to have lost all they had as sources of livelihood along with whatever movable assets they had accumulated over generations. Having resettled on their own land with almost nothing but the housing assistance from the AUP pro- grammes, they are struggling to start afresh. Most are totally dependent on casual daily wages, when available, to meet their day-to-day living expenses. Under such circum- stances, a grant for the construction of a full house to replace the house lost in the war or to repair a partially damaged house is received with immense gratitude. However, unless there is a supplementary component to provide adequate and appropriate livelihood and training opportunities to increase household incomes, the housing programme could turn out to be not only unsustainable but also a burden on households, especially those in relatively lower income groups. Amongst the beneficiaries there were those who had regular sources of income, but which were inadequate to support supplementary expenditures, such as housing related expenses. There were others who had, at best, irregular, casual or seasonal income which drove them to borrowing at any cost rather than exploring opportunities to increase their income levels. The chapter on Indebtedness elaborates on these conditions. This study examined some factors inhibiting beneficiary households from engaging in activities to improve their income levels, particularly, their tendency not to capitalise on the various training programmes for skills development and/or participating in any liveli- hood enhancement programmes that may have been available to them. According to the household survey, only 1% of the AUP-2012 beneficiaries have been involved in formal construction training programmes (See Annex 7 – Table 1.2.20), 65% received “informal on-site training under skilled artisans” while their respective houses were under construc-

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 44 tion, and 33% received no training of any sort. The 1% that received formal training had gone on to get employed in the construction trade as well. It is rather unfortunate that more beneficiary households had not taken advantage of this opportunity. It is also inter- esting to note that, while more than 80% of the beneficiaries in Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu and Batticaloa claimed that they had at least the informal onsite training, almost none of the beneficiaries in Mannar had been drawn to even the informal training on their building site. As a part of livelihood enhancement 20% of the beneficiaries had received some support towards agricultural crops, but 86% of these were from Batticaloa district (Table 1.2.27). It was also evident that beneficiaries regard livelihood assistance as a significant need, though only for a minority, in any housing programme. When asked what other support they would have desired to be incorporated in any future housing programme, 28% called for more livelihood assistance while only 4% wanted the quantum of the assis- tance increased and 68% had no opinion (Table 1.2.33). In terms of what additional benefits they would have desired in the current programme, more than a third opted for livelihood assistance (agricultural crops 5% and livestock 30%) while the rest voted for community based flanking measures (Table 1.2.32) In order that future housing programmes mitigate stressful financial experiences of the target groups, adequate and appropriate considerations need to be given to the liveli- hoods of beneficiaries. For example, a certain percentage of the housing grant could be set aside to support livelihood development programmes in which interested members of households could participate to receive training and other support. Since the com- mencement of the AUP programmes, there has been a strong effort to provide training in masonry, carpentry and other vocations to members of the beneficiary households. How- ever, the serious shortage of skilled labour in the target villages on the one hand and the fact that beneficiary households are struggling to make ends meet, on the other, means that the skills training programmes being implemented have fallen short of expectations. It would perhaps be necessary to conduct a focussed study to ascertain why the expected outcomes have not been achieved in these training programmes. 6.2 The AUP Programmes’ Approach to Livelihood and Training Most of the EU’s Multi-annual Indicative Programmes (MIPS) for Sri Lanka since 2008 have been dedicated to livelihood development. An exception is the AUP regional fa- cility which has been used solely to address housing needs and was not integrated into the MIPs. The possible justification that AUP-funded housing interventions have com- plemented EU livelihood interventions has not been borne out in reality as there is little geographical overlap between the two types of programme. This lack of EU programme integration has constituted a challenge for EU housing implementing partners who have been mandated to focus on housing. Since NERHP (AUP-2005 and AUP-2006) the need to include livelihood support measures within the housing programmes has been in- creasingly acknowledged by all parties. However, when it came to a decision on how to allocate funds between houses and livelihoods the EU Delegation seems to have taken

LIVELIHOODS AND TRAINING (AUP –2012) 45 the view that Sri Lankan authorities strongly preferred to dedicate AUP funds to maxim- ising house construction with an understanding that GAs would take care of livelihoods. Among the livelihood support measures training has been central. In conceptualising the Technical Assistance Package offered to the beneficiaries, skills training has in prac- tice been considered in earnest (UN-Habitat Operations Manual 2013-2015). Under this scheme, local artisans and youth were to be offered: • Training in masonry and carpentry (conducted in collaboration with NAITA and GIZ) • Skills upgrading of skilled construction labour • Joint effort in finding ways for cost-reduction and improved quality. Such training was intended for beneficiaries (or members of their households) with an interest in developing the skills required to complete their houses cost effectively. Once the skills were acquired, recognised and certified, they should be a source of livelihood generation. However, less than 4% in either of the programmes had attempted to make a career out of the skills they had acquired . Further, the non-availability of skilled and competent labour has often been cited as reasons for delays in completing the house constructions in the two programmes, which illustrates the demand for such skilled labour in the districts where the programmes are operational. The beneficiary survey conducted for this study found that 77% of AUP-2010 beneficiar- ies and 91% of those in AUP-2012 have claimed that they received training, of whom, 63% of AUP-2010 and 87% of AUP-2012 received training in construction related ac- tivities. There were instances of beneficiaries having acquired skills while in the refugee camps. Those who had been traditional farmers from Mannar district when relocated around the fishing villages of Kalpitiya in the Puttalam district had acquired fishing skills and on return to Mannar had engaged in fishing for a livelihood in addition to agriculture (Case Study 10). Some others had not been able to use these skills productively either in their house construction or in generating an income (Case Study 15, in the second part of this report). 6.3 Life Beyond the Construction Phase As is explained in Chapter 7 on Indebtedness, a large majority of beneficiaries in the north and some in Batticaloa are carrying significant post-construction debts, which could only be settled if there are flows of steady incomes to the beneficiaries. A general attitude of the beneficiaries towards these debts is that “…help would arrive from some- where someday….will wait for such a day…” – a clear case of dependency syndrome (see also Chapter Four on Dependency). Future programmes should be conceived to avoid such levels of dependency on external assistance. On a positive note, a very few have taken the debt burden seriously and have already sought and got employment in other parts of the country and overseas, mainly in the Middle East. However, for there to be more such job seekers among the beneficiaries, adequate skills are required and/ or placement counselling should be in place. In this regard, there are a few constraints to overcome.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 46 6.4 Lack of Vocational Skills Training Vocational skills such as masonry, carpentry, plumbing and electrical works are in great demand, but there are inadequate formal training opportunities (other than the afore- mentioned training on the house the beneficiaries construct) and/or awareness among the target communities for making a vocation and livelihood from these demands. Other vocations in perpetual demand and for which training could be provided are sewing, housekeeping (for overseas markets), computing (data entry), motor mechanics, poultry farming, animal husbandry and many more. The evaluation team interviewed the Batticaloa District Manager of NAITA and the Of- ficer-In-Charge of the Kallady Vocational Training Centre (VTC) in the same city. NAITA has training centres located around the District but unfortunately does not provide mo- bile training to villages. This would be an expensive training option for villagers who would have to meet transport and accommodation costs, if they were expected to travel to these training centres. Kallady VTC, however, is one of fourteen Rural Vocational Training Centres (RVTCs) in Batticaloa District which take training to the villages. Courses lead to certificates which are nationally recognized so can be used in applying for jobs. After six months’ training trainees are required to carry out six months on-the-job training with an employer near the village which has been found by the RVTC. Moreover, trainees receive Rs.2,000 per month as a stipend and when training on-the-job the employer is expected to provide payment. There are no fees for construction-based courses (although other courses cost Rs.8,000 per month). 6.5 Post-training investments for livelihood development When asked why no members of the family had sought any kind of training, a typical answer was that with such big debts to carry there is no way that they would be able to pay for training as well. Some had cattle and/or poultry before they were displaced by the war and would be interested in continuing with such livelihoods, but they wouldn’t be able to afford to buy new livestock while burdened with current debts. Even those with interests in sewing or computing as careers, the mere thought of having to invest on sewing machines or computers after the training constrains them from considering these vocations. 6.6 Recommendations 1. Housing grant packages need to consider an element of livelihood development in consultation with beneficiaries. These could be for formal vocational training (as op- posed to the current scheme of training offered in each beneficiary’s own house construction) or setting up a home based livelihood activity; 2. A focussed review of all AUP programmes linked to formal as well as informal training schemes need to be conducted in order for future housing programmes to be better designed to increase livelihood development while addressing the labour shortage;

LIVELIHOODS AND TRAINING (AUP –2012) 47 3. Opportunities should be sought to collaborate with Rural Vocational Training Centres such as those in Batticaloa District and described above for formal vocational training; 4. Where households are able to nominate one or two members for vocational training, they could be given bonus points in the selection process; 5. Those being sent on training could also draw a nominal allowance during training, except where these are already provided by the training organisation, such as RVTCs, to motivate more to take up the opportunity. The allowance could be, at least, equiv- alent to average daily wage they would normally earn; 6. If this allowance is considered unsustainable because of the numbers involved, it could be disbursed as a training loan to be paid back after a certain period on becom- ing gainfully employed. The loan could be from a revolving fund to be set up by the state or NGO or a partnership of the two facilitated by one or more IPs; 7. For those households who prefer to pursue a livelihood activity such as cattle farming, poultry farming or to set up a small enterprise like a tailoring shop an appropriate grant plus loan scheme could be built in to the housing programme. For such a scheme to be introduced, a clear understanding of all related aspects needs to be comprehended; 8. An awareness campaign on the benefits of livelihood development/vocational train- ing should precede the selection process.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 48 7 Indebtedness The MTE cited a Centre for Poverty Analysis (CEPA) study conducted in three northern districts of Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu, which suggested that the housing pro- grammes had significantly increased indebtedness of beneficiary households (Romeshun, et al, 2014). This finding, however, has been contested at various fora because unsus- tainable debt involves many other factors (e.g. while borrowing to build a house is a fun- damental practice in any economy, having intermediaries lending at up to 30% interest rates is not and is exploitative). What is perhaps relevant to this evaluation is not whether the housing programmes caused indebtedness (and the study is careful to state that there is no direct causality) but the impact of high levels of indebtedness on the sustainability of the housing programmes and the overall living conditions of the beneficiaries. 7.1 Extent of indebtedness According to the CEPA study, 85% of all households reported indebtedness with an av- erage of Rs. 150,871. However, as this sample included those who had not commenced construction, not all the debts could be attributed to the housing programme. The MTE, on the other hand, found that the debt situation had improved between AUP-2010 and AUP-2012. The beneficiary survey done for the MTE revealed that from among the AUP-2010 beneficiaries, 83% were found to be carrying debts, all related to house con- struction, while there was a marked drop among the AUP-2012 beneficiaries at 68%. However, in the survey done for the current AUP-2012 Final Evaluation 93% of benefi- ciaries had claimed to have borrowed for the construction of their house but only 72% find it to be a problem (see Annex 7 – tables 1.2.34 and 1.2.35). What was hypothesised in the MTE has proven correct according to the current survey: while the AUP-2010 sam- ple contained all those who had completed their houses, the lower percentage of debt- ors in the AUP-2012 sample then included beneficiaries of houses still in progress, some of whom may have not reached the stage in construction requiring funds in excess of the instalments from the housing grant. The current survey done on a sample of AUP-2012 beneficiaries who had all completed the construction shows a much higher percentage of indebtedness. A scientific study exclusively on indebtedness among AUP beneficiaries would perhaps shed light on specific causes and the nature in which indebtedness occurs within communities. However, what is relevant to this study is not such specifics but the revelation of a borrowing trend emerging amongst the beneficiaries, which, if not taken into consideration and appropriately addressed in the programme design, may dilute the positive outcome of the AUP. There have been instances of relatively debt-free, highly disciplined construction practices as presented in Case Study 1. These examples need to be documented and presented to potential beneficiaries to demonstrate what can be achieved through the exercise of discipline during the construction process ( 1 ). ( 1 ) In their comments on a draft of the present report UN-Habitat informed the evaluation team that “..it also needs to be noted that SDC in its studies found that despite participatory budgeting and financial counselling for the beneficiaries, they could not prevent beneficiaries building beyond their means”.

He did borrow to add a petty shop to the front of the house, which gives him sufficient income to pay off the loan and complete the plastering of walls still outstanding. (see Case Study 1) The mid-term evaluation also showed that the AUP programmes may have caused stress to beneficiary households for the following reasons. • A requirement of the programme that beneficiaries contribute to the housing pro- cess through the offer of their mostly unskilled labour, though well intended, may compete with the time necessary to go out and earn a living for the period of house construction, especially for those dependent on casual labour opportunities; • When income is reduced, some are driven to taking loans to cover living expenses, which are compounded when construction loans are added on; • When the house construction is complete, beneficiaries are dependent on the mea- gre income from whatever irregular casual labour is available to settle all outstanding debts in addition to spending on the family’s daily living needs; • Despite having completed the house to the level required to receive the full grant, there are still houses with some incomplete features such as plastering of walls and fixing doors and windows. Only a steady income which is enough to allow saving beyond living expenses would see these features completed. This study found the conditions leading to formal as well as informal borrowing at ex- orbitant interest rates ( 1 ) affect the majority of AUP beneficiaries to varying degrees. The beneficiary survey found that, while the acquisition of a permanent home brought a lot of joy to the beneficiaries, the indebtedness had caused substantial anxiety, anguish and ( 1 ) Households interviewed for the case studies indicated borrowing at 3% per month from local money lenders.

Of them, 29% had constant quarrels at home; 15% had lost pawned goods; and others had various other stressful experiences (see table 1.2.36)

THE CONSTRUCTION PROCESS 51 8 The construction process 8.1 Overall consideration: high quality of houses The MTE found that overall quality of the houses within AUP-2012 was good and this is confirmed in the 17 additional observations made during the final evaluation mission. The reasons for this are the same as given in the MTE ( 1 ). In addition, evaluators were pleased to hear from beneficiaries’ family members about their high level of satisfaction with living in the new houses, in terms of sense of security, sense of good investment for the future, houses perceived good quality and robustness, beauty (providing social estimation), technical resilience ( 2 ). 8.2 Supervision of construction Observations made in the final evaluation also revealed some insights into how IPs and beneficiaries worked together. In one of the observations it was noted that all the houses built in Puthuvely village (Mannar district) ( 3 ) have some interesting common features such as the main door being on the gable wall (which is a good option in case the house is expanded). Here Vashtu prescriptions are not followed (because of the beneficiaries’ Muslim faith) so that the internal organisation of space is free and independent of the imposition of measures and proportions. In a second case, in another district, the IP lost control of some beneficiaries’ construction in terms of layout, design and technical actions. The reason for this is unclear. One case is especially alarming ( 4 ). Here the proposed design was completely changed by the benefi- ciary, who decided instead on an over-ambitious ‘dream house’ which resulted in failure and leaving the house in an incomplete state ( 5 ). In addition, certain Vashtu prescriptions are currently dramatically inhibiting the daily use of the kitchen (with unexpected and undesirable consequences in a family with children) and the internal toilet (accessible through an unnecessary corridor) which is highly malodorous. External doors are also missing and the log-book was not available at the time of the visit. The evaluation team does not know how or when this lack of proper technical guidance was allowed to occur, who allowed it, who failed to warn the beneficiary of the impracticality of their prefer- ence and who failed to prevent or mitigate this action. Unfortunately, this vindicates one of the more critical technical comments made in MTE report which stated: ( 1 ) From MTE (page 48): “Drawings and technical specifications provide a sufficient set of details; The beneficiaries fully trusted both the Engineers and T.O.’s recommendations and duly followed their instructions and technical explanations”. ( 2 ) More information on satisfaction with the programme is given in Chapter Nine ( 3 ) See Observations nos. 22, 23, 24 ( 4 ) See Observation no. 17 ( 5 ) It is especially painful to point out that this house was considered “completed” in January 2016 (actually it is very much still in progress) and the MTE recommendations should have been applied in timely manner.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 52 beneficiaries have been left with excessive freedom of decision over technical aspects whereas engineers’ opinion should not be amendable ( 1 ) This should serve as a clear word of warning to AUP-2014 IPs. Another significant observation was the almost total rejection of pre-cast doors and win- dows frames, mostly due to Vashtu prescriptions. All of those interviewed during the 2016 mission, both the AUP-2012 beneficiaries and the potential applicants for AUP- 2014, believe such materials should not be used in a permanent private house and should only be used for public buildings or experimental houses. It was confirmed, during all observations made, that construction follow-up from IPs’ Technical Officers, Engineers and Community Mobilisers was timely and complete. They visited each and every site at least twice a week, which was generally sufficient to ensure good implementation (leaving aside the slow overall rate of construction ( 2 )). The obser- vations found that TOs and Engineers were still very warmly welcomed by all beneficiaries even after some time after completion. Beneficiaries stated they had been very proactive and technically supportive during the procurement and construction phases. This recommendation remains technically reasonable and will lead to financial savings ( 1 ). Many beneficiaries justified the height of the spine wall ( 2 ) in terms of heat extraction. However, this was already refuted in the MTE report ( 3 ). Our position is that only a mezza- nine, designed in the future, could reasonably justify the excessive height. In general, the more family members contributed to construction, the less money was spent on skilled and/or unskilled labour, confirming the programme’s intentions in this respect. 8.5 Materials quality tests During the FTE mission no further strength compressive block tests could be carried out because of the absence of cement blocks available and suitable for testing (construction work had finished more than a year earlier). Evaluators asked the IP to provide them with official documents showing the results of tests spontaneously carried out during the con- struction period ( 2 ) but this request was unsuccessful. However, our numerous visual observations confirm the good results reported for the MTE ( 3 ). 8.6 Toilets It is confirmed that toilets have been one very significant improvement in the housing programme AUP-2012. It is important to partially revise what had been noted in the MTE: In the Kilinochchi e Mullaitivu districts (Full and Repair Houses) detached toilets have often been built many metres away from the house (a paradox, taking into consideration the danger of snakes and overall insecurity, especially during the night). This choice is due to the perception, rooted in the traditional thinking mainly among rural Sri Lankans, particularly of the Tamils and especially in the northern districts, that a toilet in any form is “dirty” and hence needs to be de- tached and located at a distance from the main house (4) (only the urban elites are comfortable with internal toilets) . By confirming these findings, the reason why such a preference is given should be recon- sidered, since many potential applicants of future AUP-2014 highlighted that “detached toilets would be preferable because of the hygienic justification, due to scarcity of wa- ( 1 ) From MTE, page 60: “Many female family members carried out activities such as mixing concrete, moving water and blocks, casting blocks, treating wood elements, preparing meals for the labourers. Many Obser- vations carried on, show verandas made by proper and solid concrete poles, with fair tightness between vertical and horizontal elements, or through salvaged or raw materials (wood poles); the practical outcome being the same (protect from sun rays and rain; allow family to have a natural extension of the internal living space; giving the family the opportunity to develop a livelihood activity; giving the children a protected playground; etcetera), obviously the performances, the costs and the technical quality will be different according to the materials and the techniques used.
