The above points from people are correct and Evaluation Team does not state anything going opposite the practicality of a reasonable lifestyle. An alternative reservoir approach was identified on the way to Mannar which is described in the second part of the report (section on sanitation) as it has potential for incorpora- tion in the new AUP-2014. 8.9 Use of appropriate alternative technologies Within the last phase of AUP-2012, alternative construction materials and/or technolog- ical alternatives have been hardly used for the construction of the houses; as reported in the MTE, this has been mainly due to the extreme shortage of building material available that differs from the local customs, to the costs potentially linked to the transport, the possibly higher prices of new materials themselves and to the lack of specific technical knowledge ( 1 ) of the unskilled labour employed. Moreover, culturally, new material and/ ( 1 ) Fixing sashes needs some more technical skills and training than traditional wood frames

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 60 or technologies cause a certain level of mistrust and fear among the population, thus making the use of new elements difficult. Many amongst interviewed potential applicants under AUP-2014 showed a very high interest in bulk purchasing as much as possible of construction materials (such as: tiles, wood components, cement blocks, sand and cement), sharing transportation costs and optimising logistics; this witnesses about a solid social cohesion existing in the villages and a clear picture about purchasing bigger quantities at more competitive prices. 8.10 Recommendations and Lessons Learnt As mentioned in the MTE report, the overall technical quality of the houses is good, and all materials have been appropriately procured, treated, used and partly maintained. Some improvements have been observed, mainly concerning a new veranda in the main front (wood poles and tin-sheets), plastering and/or painting new house surfaces and power supplying by their own means or loaning further money. All beneficiaries highlighted the Technical Officers’ (TOs) crucial role in orienting and sup- porting them during the construction period; their appreciation is very large and many stated that “without TOs this outcome wouldn’t be possible”. TOs’ role was not only supportive in technical terms (materials, techniques) but also from procurement and management side at large, by supporting and orient CBOs to organize bulk purchases, selecting suppliers, testing materials. Unfortunately, MTE technical recommendations (see particularly MTE report pp. 50-51 and 70-71) did not have a real impact and were not taken into any practical account; actually, engineers claimed that those recommendations were officialised only in January 2015, when the houses had been completed or in an advanced stage, however those technical recommendations (ridge height; cross ventilation; limiting beneficiaries’ free initiatives beyond their possibilities; etc.) had been repeatedly urged during the many Observations, and discussed in detail during both the workshop held in Kilinochchi on 17/09/2014 and the debriefing held in Colombo on 25/09/2014 ( 1 ). Generally beneficiaries said houses are easily maintainable and nobody complained about it; also internal kitchen displayed a very good technical functionality (chimney is full per- forming in removing the smoke) and allowing women to cook and look after children at once, even during strong rains or during the night. A long-term vision (the house is expected to last for at least two generations) is largely notable throughout many interviewees; beneficiaries have returned after 20-30 years of continued displacement and a complete lack of roots (livelihood, social networks, homes, etc.) marks their lives. Since they display a fair knowledge of their future possibilities (ba- sically they do not expect great changes in their lives, unless restarting a fair job-income ( 1 ) In their comments on a draft of this report UN-Habitat stated “… over 3,000 houses were well into wall construction of which almost 2,300 had commenced roof construction by September 2014. There was little that could be incorporated from these particular recommendations at this stage.”

THE CONSTRUCTION PROCESS 61 chain to stabilise their near future), they point out the house as the very element to bet on, to turn a brand new page in their family’s life; any change regarding the house (new materials; restriction to Vashtu prescriptions; twinning the houses; etc.) are badly per- ceived as they potentially affect that abovementioned simple goal.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 62 9 The Participatory Process This evaluation looked for evidence on the nature of beneficiary participation in the AUP- 2012 programme. There was encouraging evidence of very high involvement of ben- eficiaries in the construction of their own houses as well as in those of others in the community. However, the study also concluded that there could have been and should have been greater participation in some other aspects of the programme discussed be- low. Being promoted as an “Owner Driven Programme”, it is expected that the AUP pro- grammes employ participatory strategies at all stages of the programme. Such an ap- proach would result in a greater degree of success in the programme as beneficiaries, as primary stakeholders, tend to take “ownership” of the programme by actively involving in all aspects of the programme. This study has observed a great deal of beneficiary participation in three forms. Firstly, they have been involved in the design and construction of their own houses. When asked about their levels of satisfaction in this regard almost 90% rated it at 8 or above on a 1 to 10 scale with 10 being highest level of satisfaction (see Annex 7 – Table 1.2.12). The district of Batticaloa scored a high 98% at this satisfaction level while Mannar only had a score of 63%. It is unclear to the evaluators why there was such a variation between the two districts. The reason why such high average proportion of beneficiaries felt satisfied with their involvement was because they had the opportunity to see the plan of the house to be constructed (57% felt this was important) and all aspects of the construction was with their consent and cooperation (30%). Strangely, only 12% cited all aspects of the construction being as they desired as the reason for their levels of satisfaction (An- nex 7 – Table 1.2.15). Secondly, though not to a very great extent, they have voluntarily assisted in the construction of other houses in the village with a 62% participation rate (Annex 7 – Table 1.2.16). Of those who did not participate a significant 18% felt that it was improper to interfere in others’ affairs. Thirdly, they have contributed their skills, time and labour towards various aspects in the overall planning and implementation of the programmes or in the planning and/or the construction of community infrastructure initiated through AUP programmes. Perhaps the only serious concern is the inadequate involvement of the beneficiaries in the beneficiary selection process and in the generation of model plans for beneficiaries to choose from. The theoretical “ownership” that stakeholder participation is expected to bring to a pro- gramme was quite evident in the pride most beneficiaries expressed while describing their experiences. Some talked of how much they contributed in labour towards the

THE PARTICIPATORY PROCESS 63 construction. The relatively high levels of stakeholder participation in the housing process could be attributed to the involvement of the Village Rehabilitation Committees (VRCs). The VRC is a ten-member committee in each GN Division made up of AUP programme beneficiaries in each of those GN Divisions. Their roles have been varied – advocacy to facilitation of skilled labour hire and bulk material purchase to mobilising voluntary unskilled labour. In almost all VRCs there had been a tendency for members of other village level CBOs (Community Based Organisations) such as RDS (Rural Development Society) and WRDS (Women’s Rural Development Society) to be voted in as members. This perhaps is a rural political phenomenon where persons acting with authority in an existing organisation are perceived to be influential enough in the village to be repeatedly voted in to take on any new position being created in the village. For this reason, doubts have been raised as to whether there is a real need for VRCs and if all activities current- ly carried out by them could not be assigned to existing CBOs. There is no doubt that the VRCs, formed exclusively for the housing programme, are performing well and have made significant contributions towards the positive outcomes of the AUP programme. It is doubtful that CBOs formed for other purposes and reporting to different agencies would be as conscientious as VRCs have been. Would these other CBOs, for instance, obtain quotes from local traders for the supply of various building materials and arrange for their purchase in bulk for groups of beneficiaries resulting in cheaper and better qual- ity building materials? Would they be able to bring in skilled labour when required by the beneficiaries and, most importantly, mobilise volunteers to provide unskilled labour to the most vulnerable in the village? 9.1 Recommendations • Housing designs need to be flexible enough to accommodate beneficiary inputs at a very early stage in the process. Ideally, workshops should be organised for potential beneficiaries at convenient locations to jointly generate the type plans. This would be a great opportunity, not only to draw in user inputs into the design of the type plans, but also to make the potential beneficiaries aware of the likely financial and other hardships to be encountered when deviating from the type plan. Case studies of good practices as well as bad practices with reasons for both need to be made aware of to all beneficiaries • A mechanism to solicit and include target group suggestions to improve the benefi- ciary selection process should be built into the programmes. This idea appears in the AUP-2014 proposal presented by HfH and WVL. • Regular workshops for community leaders (perhaps for groups of VRCs) with experi- enced facilitators should be scheduled to implement community action plans such as the SIP.

CONCLUSIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS 65 11 Conclusions & Recommendations 11.1 Introduction In this chapter we look at both the conclusions and recommendations of the evaluation. However, we shall not be listing or reviewing either. They are detailed and summarised in the forgoing chapters. Many are the same as presented in the report of the mid-term evaluation which took place in September 2014. Some of them have been adopted in the design for the AUP-2014 programme. Here, however, we wish to concentrate on the overall conclusions and recommendations - those which can be used to guide the future direction and design of the AUP programmes. 11.2 Positive Features of the AUP Programmes The global objective of AUP-2012 is “to address medium term rehabilitation needs of returnees and their host communities in the North and East of Sri Lanka” with the key indicators being: “the number of returnees benefiting directly from improved housing, flanking infrastructure, training in construction or tenure title regularisations as a result of the action”. The target set for these indicators is 19,600 people which the programme easily surpassed with 71,489. The reasons the implementing partner gives for such a large difference in the figures are that it made foreign exchange rate gains, achieved savings on operations costs and required increased beneficiary contributions (UN-Habitat, 2016: 30). There are many positive features but the following are some of the most notable: 1. There is a very high-level of beneficiary satisfaction , not simply because they now have a permanent house instead of temporary dwellings but because of the technical quality of the houses. The field survey shows that 94% of beneficiaries were very sat- isfied with the programme; 2. As a result the EU, UN-Habitat and SDC are all held in very high regard ( 1 ); 3. There was a high-level of home owner participation but somewhat more in the construction than the design of the houses where shortcomings have been iden- tified in Chapter Eight. There has been an attempt to take local culture into ac- count though, as pointed out in parts of the report this is not everywhere the case. Toilets are a case in point. In some districts detached toilets have been built to ad- dress perceptions that toilets are “dirty” and must be at a distance from the main house; 4. There are parts of the programme where women’s participation is clearly visible, most notably in the implementation and management of the construction process and in the leadership of the VRCs. UN-Habitat-provided leadership training which undoubtedly contributed to this; ( 1 ) Though AusAID/DFAT was a donor it was never specifically mentioned by discussants in the FGDs

UNMEASUR- ABLE 11.3 Learning the Big Lessons In this section we consider how this positive performance can be taken into the future, such as in the AUP-2014 which was launched in December 2015 and future potential housing-related programmes. AUP has already gone through five phases and donors and implementing agencies have shown themselves capable of learning from the first when designing the following. Similarly, they are now keen to learn from the lessons of Phase II or, rather, from the combined lessons of Phases I and II ( 1 ). Below we present what we believe to be the most important of these. 11.3.1 General Considerations of the AUP Approach The preceding chapters have identified several important problems which have not been solved during the implementation of AUP-2012 or preceding programmes such as de- pendency, indebtedness and low sustainability. We believe that these can at least in part be traced to the model of home owner driven development as practised in the Owner Driven Model approach in Sri Lanka. We shall explain why and go on to propose how the model can be transformed to make use of its existing strengths while acquiring essential new ones. ( 1 ) In the workshop held in Kilinochchi with IPs the participants showed that they had numerous ideas of how to improve the AUP some of which coincide with the evaluation team’s ideas. This is a positive sign demonstrating willingness to learn from their own experiences.

CONCLUSIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS 71 The Irony of the Home Owner Driven Approach In Chapter Four we argued that the home owner driven approach has largely failed to ex- ploit the development of a cooperative social fabric or created opportunities for integrat- ed development which could enhance the resilience of individuals and communities. This is because the approach adopted has been sectorial (i.e. housing) and has focused on individual household participation in the design and construction of houses rather than village approaches such as practised by SDC. Flanking work has provided some broader community benefits but little to make community actions sustainable (e.g. CBOs capable of community level planning, financing, implementation and maintenance). As explained in Chapter Four the focus on housing was required by the donor in the call for propos- als ( 1 ) with the reasoning that it complemented multiple parallel livelihood development projects in existence at the time. However, this complementarity is more theoretical than real in so far as they do not always coincide geographically. The Unwanted Consequences The home owner driven approach has not managed to overcome, and at times might have exacerbated, problems of unsustainable indebtedness, dependency syndrome and the low sustainability of community and possibly individual assets. This is not to say that the approach is the only cause but it has contributed to it. The way it has done so we present graphically as an interconnected process in the figure below. Home Owner Driven Approach Weak CBOs Individualistic development Low sustainability Indebtedness Low ownership of community assets Dependency Figure 17: The Interconnected Process of the Home Owner Driven Approach, Indebtedness, Dependency and Low Sustainability The emphasis on the home owner taking the lead in decisions about his/her house has unintentionally contributed to further indebtedness which home owners cannot manage. Meanwhile the individualistic house-centred approach leaves CBOs weak (though social cohesion is high) and ownership of community assets low. This results in a dependent attitude to the sustainability of the latter. ( 1 ) Source: UN-Habitat, response to the draft evaluation report

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 72 The Shape of Future Housing Assistance Programmes in Sri Lanka The MTE evaluation team believed that as AUP-2012 ended one should consider design- ing a different developmental model for future housing programmes. It would address the key problems of dependency and indebtedness and ensure that benefits are not only sustainable but more widely enjoyed as explicitly formulated in the Action Document for AUP-2014. An ideal approach places not the individual but the community at the heart, not hand-outs but partnership, not a programme which ends when the project closes, but which continues through strengthened community organisations. This model would be more holistic than in AUP programmes up to and including AUP-2012. Transition- ing from household to a form of integrated rural settlement development which would combine housing assistance with major components of livelihoods and micro-enterprise development would provide for a more balanced approach. The People’s Process: a Community Driven Approach One can see this approach in the model of the “People’s Process” which has been sup- ported successfully by UN-Habitat in many resettlement and reconstruction programmes in South and South-East Asia (Lankatilleke, 2009 and no date, UN-Habitat 2010e). It starts from the premise that while families need a house, they also live in communities and have a responsibility to each other. While households need houses communities need services such as water, sanitation, roads, power, civic facilities, child-care and el- derly-care support. Satisfying community needs requires collective, not individual, effort. This extension from the individual to the community is what is articulated as the People’s Process of housing and settlement development. The figure below presents graphically how this approach would address indebtedness and contribute to sustainability. By strengthening CBOs and providing livelihoods-related training, internal organisational capacity and funds should be generated to both reduce indebtedness and make community asset formation feasible. CBOs would be strength- ened not only through leadership training but also through a concerted effort to develop community contracting. These would involve both contracts with local government to undertake construction and maintenance work but also in the non-construction indus- tries such as tailoring, metalwork or farm based enterprises. These trades would be de- veloped through a livelihoods programme.

CONCLUSIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS 73 Community Driven Approach CBO Strengthening High sustainability Livelihoods & Training Lower indebtedness, more disposable income Community assets produced Community ownership Community planning & implementation Figure 18: The Relationships between the Community Driven Approach, Indebtedness and Sustainability Because it is concerned with the whole village the community driven approach to ben- eficiaries is that all families need to benefit and not only some. This implies examining approaches to construction which are lower-cost (so that the available funds stretch fur- ther than they do at present and can reach even the extremely poor) and this leads to the consideration of incremental housing and lower-cost alternative materials. Both of these will require the inclusion of robust awareness programmes. It is unfortunate that the approach adopted so far, which has delivered relatively large complete houses through grants, is likely to have created resistance to the introduction of incremental housing and the use of lower-cost building materials. More Questions This raises the question of whether a grant or whole grant approach is desirable. The full grant approach is likely to create dependence rather than self-driven development ( 1 ). Alternative funding mechanisms should be sought which emphasise a partnership rather than donor-recipient relationship for households that can afford to put some savings aside. These could include part grant-part own savings arrangements (e.g. 80% - 20%). And it would also encourage home owners to look more favourably on lower cost solu- tions. The own saving contribution would be in addition to the present provision of home owner labour. The incremental approach to housing coupled with part-granting would reduce the amount of ‘up-front’ grant cash required by the programme for housing. This could be invested instead in livelihoods activities. ( 1 ) In an interview with Habitat for Humanity in Batticaloa we were told that the experience of grants, in the form of housing, as part of the post-tsunami reconstruction process, led to such dependency that many beneficiaries even stopped working as they came to expect that all their needs would be met by an external agent.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 74 In an interview with CEPA the team was asked whether housing was even the priority of beneficiary communities ( 1 ). The only way to be sure is to ask them, of course. We believe, however, from the responses received during our focus group discussions, that priorities are multiple and that as houses become less of a priority, others become more important. The community driven approach is well equipped to identify and address the range of community needs and priorities. A final thought, on the question of how broadly one should aim to spread the benefits of a housing programme, is this. One can consider spending almost another €160 million on solving the whole problem of remaining war-destroyed or damaged houses in the North and East based on the current approach. This would solve the problem for today, which would of course be laudable. However, it does little for future generations and the needs of newly formed households. As the children of present beneficiaries grow up and start their own families they will require housing. The AUP programmes can leave an important legacy if they establish a housing finance mechanism which is accessible to young households. For them houses will need to be affordable and they will not have the benefit of the grants their parents have had. This will probably mean they have to look for the kind of incremental housing promoted in this report, including the use of alternative building materials. It is recommended that in a future AUP programme part of the funding be set aside to establish such a financing mechanism. What are the prospects? The above recommendations were directed partly at AUP-2012 as it prepared to enter its last nine months but, because this is a short period in which to incorporate a wide range of recommendations, they were mainly aimed at future AUP programmes. Since the mid- term evaluation report was written a new programme, AUP-2014, has been established which started its activities in December 2015, although it had not yet begun field imple- mentation when the present evaluation and baseline study took place in March and April 2016. What does its project design tell us about the way in which it differs from previous programmes and the extent to which it incorporates the recommendations of the mid- term evaluation (largely restated in the present report)? Here we will briefly mention what we believe are the most significant design features ( 2 ). The beneficiary selection process has been identified as a source of dissatisfaction in this report largely because worthy applicants, as perceived by communities, have been declined a grant. AUP-2014 takes up this challenge and will introduce community par- ticipation in the selection process. It will also reconsider applicants above and below a preliminary cut-off level rather than automatically exclude those who fall below it. Both these correspond to recommendations made in the MTE of AUP-2012. ( 1 ) In a focus group discussion in Mulliwaikkal East (Mullaitivu District) on 5 th April 2016 participants were asked whether housing was a priority for them. There followed a heated discussion amongst participants, some of whom were arguing that if support were given to their current livelihoods problems they would earn more money than they would receive from the programme for housing. The village was a candidate for the AUP-2014 programme. ( 2 ) Fuller details can be found in HfH (2015).

CONCLUSIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS 75 A range of house designs (four) will be offered with differing levels of grant. The designs cover ten house types. In seven of these cases grants will be supplemented by loans of between 2.7% and 22% of the total house cost. This aims to reduce dependency while offering most grant support to the neediest. Loans will be available through a non-ex- ploitative micro-finance institution in an attempt to prevent indebtedness. Livelihoods support including skills training and micro-enterprise development (e.g. in the production of alternative building materials) also aim to ward off indebtedness as well as increase living standards. Many grants will be smaller and therefore five of the house types are for smaller houses. This is in an attempt to provide houses which match need rather than have one size for all, optimise the use of grants and provide a wider spread of benefits. The same intention lies behind having three of the four house designs incorporate alternative building mate- rials including sun-dried brick and compressed stabilised earth block. This will be a major challenge to implement as resistance will be high. As with previous AUPs, training will be provided to CBOs in order to strengthen local ca- pacity for sustainability which will also benefit from increased incomes of home owners. All the terms underlined were key focus areas of the mid-term evaluation of AUP-2012 which have been restated in the present report. The fact that AUP-2014 is addressing them, including using the recommendations made by the evaluation team, we think bodes well for the future. However, major changes bring with them major challenges which AUP-2014 will certainly encounter. The evaluation team believes AUP-2014 is set on the right track and expects it to add to the wealth of experience and good practices which have been built up so far by AUP-2012 and preceding AUP programmes.

BACKGROUND Until 2009, two decades of conflict left nearly 365,000 houses fully or partially damaged in the Northern and Eastern Provinces of Sri Lanka. This further aggravated the conse- quences over populations previously affected by the Tsunami in December 2004 which also provoked massive destruction throughout most of Sri Lanka’s coastline, notably in the East and North-East. After the declared end of the conflict in May 2009 the international community rein- forced efforts in assisting Sri Lanka reconstruct social infrastructure and livelihoods main- ly in conflict-affected areas. These have involved a new wave of permanent housing reconstruction led mainly by donors such as the EU, Australian Aid, Swiss Development Cooperation and more recently the High Commission of India. Housing reconstruction has been building up on experiences from the post-tsunami such as the “Home Own- er-Driven” approach earlier consolidated by UN-Habitat in Sri Lanka. Since 2005, EU support to housing reconstruction in Sri Lanka has already resulted in 16,000 houses benefiting over 64,000 people. Four programmes have involved the fol- lowing Implementing Partners in chronological order: the World Bank (2005-2008), ASB (2008-2013) and UN-Habitat (2010-2014 and 2013-2015). By 2015, the EU expects to have contributed to funding the reconstruction of 20,000 houses (approximately 10,000 in the North and 10,000 in the East). The most important allocation of the Indian-funded programme is being implemented by UN-Habitat also, which simplifies donor-coordination at the field level. ANNEx 1 – TERMS OF REFERENCE 79 From post-emergency to development In January 2010 the ‘International Monetary Fund’ (IMF) upgraded Sri Lanka to ‘Middle Income Emerging Markets’. And recently, the Government of Sri Lanka, has declared that the “humanitarian phase is over”. Accordingly, a number of humanitarian donors (e.g.: ECHO) and many INGOs have withdrawn and ‘Official Development Assistance’ (ODA) has been shifting focus from post-emergency (e.g. transitional shelter and WATSAN) to development (e.g. permanent housing and flanking measures). Development agencies such as DfID have recently withdrawn their permanent offices from Colombo. However, according to the ‘Sri Lanka Human Development Report 2012’: “Development oppor- tunities are skewed towards a few urban centres, resulting in migration to cities and poor living standards in several rural provinces. Prevailing inequalities and disparities have adversely impacted the growth potential as well as the equitable human development of all people living in the country”. Growth and infrastructure development in the richer Western Province where almost half of the national GDP is accounted for, contrasts with progress in the North and the East. Whilst Government has committed to undertake large social permanent housing pro- grammes nationwide, low-cost housing reconstruction in the North and East remains mainly dependant on ODA and diaspora remittances. Despite international efforts, ODA will not cover the gap in housing needs on a “house-for-a-house” basis estimated for 2015 to remain between 60,000 and 100,000 in the North only. UN-Habitat guesses that another 20,000 houses are needed in the Eastern District of Batticaloa. Community-build- ing, livelihood development and access to basic social infrastructure for the poorest in rural areas remain a crucial developmental challenge requiring local sustainable solutions. Current situation in the reconstruction sector Large-scale infrastructure (e.g. national roads and energy supply network) are quickly spreading in the South West and steadily reaching the North and East. Housing recon- struction for IDPs has also been determined as top priority for Government but ad- vances are yet to materialise. The wide-spread location of returnee villages throughout rural areas does not make it easier. Returnee immigration, such as many among the 50,000 Sri Lankan refugees in India, puts pressure on land resources. There are concerns over instances of interventionism in land dispute resolutions and the number of landless remains a serious challenge to be addressed. Whilst beneficiary selection has been man- aged with scoring systems accounting for vulnerability, the rise of political interventions and favouritism in allocations to particular communities needs to be carefully monitored. The recent elections of 21 September Northern, Central and North-West provinces have resulted in a representational victory of Tamil communities winning 30 out of 36 seats in the North. The practical implications of this are yet to be seen. Whilst ODA can claim humanitarian successes on many fronts in conflict-affected Sri Lan- ka, the combination of economic devastation caused by armed conflict with an accrued form of donor-dependency have not helped towards the creation of a local and reliable construction market nor of the industrial or entrepreneurial fabric necessary to supply low-

Implementing Partners involved in reconstruction have even struggled attract labour to the construction sector. In addition, construction resourc- es (labour and materials) inflation has led to prohibitive costs for individuals left without assistance. The average size of construction contractors remains small and their reliability low as compared to a more competitive and functional market in the South and West. The EU-funded ‘Aid to Uprooted People’ housing programmes in Sri Lanka The post-tsunami emergency context of 2005 led the European Commission to under- take major commitments to support social-infrastructure and livelihood projects. Housing reconstruction, in particular, has been financed under the EU’s regional facility called ‘Aid to Uprooted People’ (AUP). The first two AUP programmes for housing reconstruction in Sri Lanka contributed with EUR 6,000,000 in 2005 and EUR 10,000,000 in 2006 to the ‘North East Reconstruc- tion Programme’ (NEHRP) led by the World Bank and Government. By that stage, the ‘Home Owner Driven’ approach had already been consolidated as the main implemen- tation approach. This programme set out clear standards ( 1 ) for housing construction partly as a reaction to the plethora of spontaneous housing projects that had emerged from international solidarity response to the tsunami. Whilst the respect of these stand- ards are a condition sine qua non for implementation, a critical analysis of the same in view of pointing at ways to upgrading them are necessary particularly in view of accom- modating more flexibly the remaining housing needs. PART II BASELINE STUDY OF THE PROGRAMME Developmental Housing Reconstruction Support to Sri Lankan Internally Displaced Persons Programme funded by the EU’s Aid to Uprooted People (AUP) 2014 Action titled: Homes not Houses: Building a Sustainable Future Together Contract No DCI-ASIE/2015/369-395 Implemented by Habitat for Humanity and world Vision Lanka

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 210 1 Introduction In the terms of reference for the present evaluation it was intended that a baseline survey be carried out for AUP-2012 during the first mission. As it was, by the time the mission took place, in September 2014, AUP-2012 was already well underway and it was agreed with the EU Delegation that a mid-term evaluation be carried out instead. The baseline study would be carried out for the next AUP programme, if there was one. Such a pro- gramme was approved in 2015 which is known as AUP-2014. This is the programme which is the subject of the present baseline study. It is called a baseline study rather than survey because it consists of more than a house- hold survey and includes documentary analysis, the results of focus group discussions, semi-structured interviews, case studies and observations, as is explained in Chapter 2 below (“Methods”). Grants and the changing context of AUP-2014 The AUP-2010 and AUP-2012 offered beneficiary households grants, each worth Rs.500,000 to 550,000 to construct 550 sq. ft. houses. Recently, the GOSL decided to implement a programme of 65,000 prefabricated steel houses of the same size costing Rs.2.1 million each. The 10,000 owner-driven housing programme being implemented by local governments has also set a grant level of Rs.800,000 for a 550 sq. ft. house 1 . The Indian Housing Project has similarly raised its grant from Rs.550,000 to Rs.950,000. The present evaluation argues that a figure of around Rs.700,000 is sufficient to complete a standard house assuming that beneficiaries will always add more, regardless of whether they are obliged to or not 2 . But, in any case, the AUP-2014 grant amount should be re-assessed and fixed at a more realistic level than it now is. It should also consider whether equity is better served by raising the grant from the current Rs.550,000 level: if the other programmes are providing a significantly higher grant it would be unfair for AUP grantees to receive the far smaller amount. The implications of this, in terms of numbers of beneficiaries, should be calculated. If grants are Rs.150,000 -250,000 higher the budget will require that there be 25%-45% fewer of them. 1 This is expected to reduce debt levels because, it is believed, grantees will not need to resort to loans. However, it is still possible that they will continue to borrow in order to further improve their houses. 2 Costs can also be held down below Rs.800,000 because of a number of improvements in procurement which have been made during the successive AUPs such as with bulk purchase and the greater availability of experienced/skilled masons.

INTRODUCTION 211 Figure 1: Rearing goats as a livelihood, Kithul village, Batticaloa district (Observation no. 12 – AUP2014) Scope of the baseline study AUP-2014 is being implemented by Habitat for Humanity (HFH) and World Vision Lanka (WVL). At the time of the mission in March–April 2016 they were preparing their own baseline survey which they would use to help them monitor performance regularly and to evaluate it. The question then arises why the evaluation team should carry out a seem- ingly duplicate survey. First, the team’s study was not only a survey but employed additional methodological tools which could provide data to enrich that of the survey. The survey data itself can be used by the IPs to complement their own findings.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 212 Figure 2: Focus group discussion in Karadiyanaaru village, Batticaloa as part of baseline study (24 th March 2016) Secondly, the baseline study carried out by the evaluation team was intended to con- tribute to the IPs’ own baseline survey design. During the mission meetings were held between the team and responsible IP monitoring and evaluation staff to discuss their survey design and methodology. The baseline survey used by the evaluation team was given to the IPs before they started their own survey so that they could incorporate whatever contents they considered of value. The evaluation team’s survey questionnaire appears in Annex 1. The monitoring and evaluation system Although it was not part of its terms of reference the team considered it important to discuss with the implementing partners how they would monitor the AUP 1 . This is be- cause the mid-term and final evaluations will benefit from good monitoring data. While the IPs are aware that this exercise was not part of the ToR they were keen to receive independent suggestions from the team. Details of the team’s recommendations are given in Chapter Three. 1 In their proposal to the EU the IPs stated that they intended to carry out their own mid-term and final evaluations in addition to the independent external evaluations which the Delegation of the European Union will require.

METHODS USED FOR THE BASELINE STUDY 213 2 Methods used for the baseline study The baseline study employed four main tools: a household survey, focus group discus- sions, semi-structured interviews, case studies and observations. 2.1 Documentary analysis Before the baseline study was undertaken key project documents were read, in par- ticular the Grant Application (the concept note and project proposal). This allowed the evaluation team to inform itself of the programme scope (number of beneficiaries, geo- graphical location, etc.), the intended results (e.g. income opportunities, financial skills and the strengthening of organisational capacity as well as housing) and implementation methodology and procedures for monitoring and evaluation. 2.2 Semi-structured interviews Six interviews were carried out with HfH and WVL staff between 16 th March and 8 th April. Their purpose was obtaining information on the programme’s design and implementa- tion methodology especially insofar as these had been developed since the proposal sub- mitted to the EUD. One example of this is the methodology to be employed for carrying out the baseline survey and project monitoring. 2.3 Household Survey A local survey team was sub-contracted to carry out a household survey. It carried out a total of 259 household interviews . These comprised 99 in Mullaitivu, 97 in Kilinochchi, and 63 in Batticaloa. The purpose of the survey was to collect information on the condition of houses before the start of AUP-2014, potential beneficiaries’ perception of a ‘good house’, feelings of security, priority house improvements and livelihoods. At the time the baseline was carried out the beneficiary lists had not yet been drawn up by the IPs. It was, therefore, impossible to carry out a random survey of beneficiar- ies as was done for the final evaluation of AUP-2012. The same applies, of course, for non-beneficiaries. Instead, quota sampling was carried out in the GN divisions where it was known that the AUP-2014 would be implemented. The Sampling Frame The evaluation team had been requested by the EUD to carry out 250 surveys for the baseline study.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 214 The sample was selected by calculating the percentage of all intended beneficiaries in each district and surveying households in each district in proportion to this distribution. Households were subject to quota sampling. It was decided that the total number of villages which could be surveyed in the time available was twelve. The proportion of villages to be covered in each district was calculated in the same way. The focus group meetings were probably seen as an oppor- tunity to learn more. It is unsurprising then that meetings were over-subscribed. This list appears as Annex 1 to this report. 2.5 Case studies It was decided that at least five case studies would be carried out for the baseline study in the time available. The number of case studies per district was determined in the same way as the household survey: in proportion to the number of beneficiaries there would be in each. It was, in fact, possible to carry out 7 case studies . These were distributed across dis- tricts as follows: Batticaloa (3), Kilinochchi (2) and Mullaitivu (2). There were none done in Mannar as the AUP-2014 did not include this district. The purpose of the case studies was to gain an in-depth understanding of villagers’ opinions about housing and their preferences by learning about their life histories and current situations. While those interviewed were yet to be selected for a housing pro- gramme (the selection of beneficiaries for AUP-2014 had not commenced at the time of the evaluation and the interviewees were seen only as potential beneficiaries) it was also an opportunity to find out why these households had not been included in any of the previous programmes, how they felt about missing out and how they had coped with the situation till now. The way in which the information was gathered was through open-ended discussion.

In fact, it proved possible to carry out twenty-three observations. Observations were intended to show the conditions of houses (actually, all of the po- tential applicants visited, are currently living in shacks ) before the start of AUP-2014 which have not been subject to any previous AUP. They also reveal occupants’ preferences with regard to building materials and house design which it is hoped that the AUP-2014 Implementing Partners will find useful to take up. The houses chosen for observation were randomly selected and as many were covered as possible in the time available which exceeded the intended number. MONITORING AND EVALUATION (M&E) SYSTEM 219 3 Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) System The team discussed Habitat for Humanity International’s and World Vision Sri Lanka’s proposed monitoring system with staff responsible in each organisation. 3.1 The M&E framework The team found that the structure for collecting monitoring data is generally well thought out. HfH will focus on housing aspects while WVL will concentrate on flanking (livelihood support) measures. It will be important for the two partnering organisations to coordi- nate their two M&E systems effectively within the combined programme framework. For example, HfH has developed a baseline survey which the evaluation team reviewed and commented upon and later found a “BL Tool” which had been developed by World Vision (WVL) which is different and much more extensive. The former has good, detailed questions about livelihoods and face sheet data about respondents but also contains questions about houses which overlap with the HfHI survey. The IPs summarise the monitoring and evaluation framework they will use in their grant application (p. 24). Amongst the various procedures two planned activities are worth singling out. The first is: “HFHSL will facilitate a monthly meeting of the District Steering Committee between representatives of beneficiaries, relevant CBOs (VRC/RDS/WRDS), GN, DS or his/her nominee and any other government agencies”. As the IPs say: “This will enable speedy resolution to matters related to the project which requires government approval or intervention as well as accountability and feedback”. But it will also bring beneficiaries and their organisations into the decision making process and strengthen their self-confidence, legitimacy and credibility in further development actions outside AUP-2014 and beyond it once it has ended. Another creditable activity is described thus: “HFHSL will also organise periodic community meetings for accountability reporting” (ibid.) It is suggested that this element of the M&E system be closely monitored by manage- ment as it is one which could fall by the wayside under pressures of implementation. The team suggests that learning reviews also be carried out in which lessons learnt can be identified and fed back into the management system. The reviews could include “most significant change” (MSC) experiences from communities which can be used as inputs into the mid-term and final evaluations. World Vision already has experience with the MSC methodology so is well–placed to implement it in this programme. Given the number of monitoring activities which are envisaged by the Implementing Partners it is suggested that they consider carefully the number of field monitoring staff they will require to implement it. Their framework is a good one but will suffer if staff are too few and actions are hurried.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 220 The two partners intend to carry out mid-term and final evaluations with their own staff. This is very good: it can only facilitate internal learning and promote buy-in to the process and its results. Furthermore, it will be carried out by staff who have knowledge of the available data and are experienced in accessing it. Of course, the EU will contract external evaluators to carry out independent mid-term and final evaluations. The lead final evaluator should certainly be external and possibly the mid-term too. This is in order to provide an independent, external perspective and to ensure credibility of the findings to third parties. However, this is an initiative that is to be encouraged. There are some specific aspects of the proposed M&E system which deserve mention: First, it incorporates more qualitative measures than the preceding AUP. For example, in addition to survey, focus group discussions will be held to elicit community opinions and expectations. They intend to carry out learning reviews amongst staff and commu- nities. The partners are familiar with community based tools such as the most significant change approach. Secondly, the monitoring will be broader than in the previous AUP as it will contain a significant qualitative dimension. As mentioned above this means it will be important to have sufficient field staff. Reliance on university volunteers, rather than paid researchers, may be risky unless the IPs already have sufficient experience to show that this approach works. The evaluation team did not have time to look at this. The IPs, especially WVL, has developed a monitoring tool with which they are familiar. This is the living standards ranking survey (PLSR) which can be used for the baseline survey as well as for monitoring. Another has been developed specifically for this pro- gramme which is the Financial Literacy tool to assess and monitor indebtedness. Finally, it is recommended that the IPs look at the electronic monitoring system employed by UN-Habitat / SDC in AUP-2010 and AUP-2012 which may provide experience on which they can build, especially if it is possible to discuss with personnel responsible for management of the system and managers who used the data it produced 1 . 3.2 The Logical Framework and Performance Tracking Matrix The evaluation team analysed the logical framework with HfH staff responsible for coor- dinating the M&E activities and discussed it, to a lesser extent, with the corresponding coordinator on the side of WVL. The team has only one recommendation in this respect: Regarding indicators, it is suggested they be further developed to better reflect the in- tention to increase social cohesion and other qualitative changes (“outcomes”). This in- cludes developing a measurement tool for social cohesion. 1 It may be difficult to do this as staff from the earlier AUPs will have dissipated and there may some discomfort in their discussing with the new IPs how to continue the work they had intended to do themselves had UN-Habitat’s proposal been successful. However, this does not mean that there should be no attempt made.

MONITORING AND EVALUATION (M&E) SYSTEM 221 3.3 The Implementing Partners’ Baseline Survey 3.3.1 Comments on the implementing partners’ survey The evaluation team discussed the HfH baseline survey format with its monitoring and evaluation coordinator and suggested a number of modifications. The Implementing Partner’s survey included questions about the condition of the respondent’s house, land ownership, sanitation, water, sanitation, road access and “other information”. All infor- mation was to be gathered by the enumerator through observation with the household- er verifying his/her assessment at the end of the survey. The evaluation team suggested additional questions which would be put to the householder. One of these was to ask about the cost of the water the householder obtains; another is their opinion about alternative sanitation options including the ex- isting toilet. Additionally, there should be a question about solid waste disposal by the household. It was also suggested to include questions about what features householders thought a ‘good’ house would have (e.g. sturdiness, security, comfort, perceived status and space). The team thought it important to measure existing levels of social cohesion as part of the baseline survey the IPs would carry out, such as the extent they collaborated with neighbours and participated in community based organisations. 3.3.2 Comments on the evaluation team’s survey: limitations of the data The evaluation team took the HfH survey format, added its own suggestions and tested the modified questionnaire in the field as its own baseline survey, the results of which are reported in various parts of this report. In this section the evaluation will make a few comments on its own baseline format which the IPs may find useful in its own baseline survey design. The first comment of the evaluation team on its own survey is that some questions were not asked correctly by the enumerators. For example, question 2.2.23 looks for explanations to the answer in the previous question (whether they would accept com- pressed earth blocks as a walling material). The answer recorded was “not relevant” for all respondents whereas what was expected was a range of explanations such as “not durable” or “low status”. This shows that the enumerator did not understand the question him/herself. A thorough pilot of the survey instrument would have detected this; unfortunately the evaluation’s pilot survey failed to pick this up. The same applies to question 2.2.25. Another comment relates to whether questions should be closed or open-ended. Some of the questions are closed but will only give useful answers if they are open-ended. For example, question 2.2.26 asks respondents whether they consider “strength” to be a feature of a ‘good’ house. Similarly the following questions ask the same about comfort, protection from the elements and animals, hygiene and privacy. It is unsurprising that all

It would have been more useful to ask what respondents con- sidered to be the main features of a ‘good’ house 1 . 1 There were some other shortcomings in the survey tool and/or the data obtained from it. RESULTS OF THE BASELINE STUDY 223 4 Results of the baseline study Notwithstanding some of the weaknesses of the data identified above, the household survey produced some useful information to complement data produced by the other methods used in the baseline study. The following findings have been assembled from the baseline survey, focus group discussions, case studies and observations. Beneficiary Selection (AUP-2014) Anecdotal evidence that the AUP selection process had been somewhat unfair emerged during the Baseline Study for the AUP-2014 programme. One in particular, a young fam- ily in Mullaitivu (see Case Study 16) who had a four year old child suffering from blood cancer had been denied a house since 2010 despite their applications being strongly endorsed by medical practitioners treating the child. Their anger and frustration were heightened by the fact that another family member and his wife (a two member family) had been supported through the Indian Housing Programme to build their house in an adjoining property. The yet-to-be-beneficiary family is still hopeful that support would be coming their way very soon. Similarly, despite being injured in the war, a family, also from Mullaitivu, has still not received a housing grant (Case Study 17). Figure 8: Anomalies in the Selection Process – While a sister and her family with two young children, one seriously ill, languish in a make-shift shack (top) the brother and her wife, with no other family members, benefitted from the Indian Housing Programme (bottom) in Suthanthirapuram, Puthukudiruppu, Mullaitivu (Case Study 16). In yet another case, a female-headed household, in which the male head of household had gone missing after the military forces had taken him for interrogation in 2008, was denied a house in the AUP-2010 programme, but was successful in the AUP-2012 programme when the application was made along with documentary evidence of the missing head of household (Case Study 3).

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 224 At the time of this evaluation, it appeared that there has been a genuine attempt by the newly selected Implementing Partners (Habitat for Humanity/World Vision) to take on board the recommendations made in the MTE with respect to selection criteria being revised to reflect a higher degree of fairness. In particular, the MTE was critical of the se- lection criteria used in AUP-2012 (which had been adopted from the Indian Housing Pro- gramme) where households with unmarried female members above 18 could not count these members towards the criterion determining the size of the household and thereby being discriminated against. The recommendation was for these members to be counted towards determining the household size. However, the new selection criteria to be used in AUP-2014 has positively discriminated with respect to unmarried females over 18 in the household by including a special criterion giving additional points for those families with unmarried females over 18 and also counting them towards the size of the household. 4.1 Community Based Organisations—CBOs There are plenty of CBOs with which to work. Those present at focus group discussions were RDSs, WRDS, women’s groups, sports clubs, elders’ societies, youth societies, Com- munity Centre Groups, Dairy Farm Cooperative Society, Farmers’ Society, Fishermen’s Society, Disabled Society, Samurdhi Society and Coconut Development Society. The baseline survey shows membership of village organisations is extremely high with membership at 96-100% in the three districts of Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu and Batticaloa. For example, 26% of respondents were in both the WRDS and Samurdhi Society and another 26% in the Samurdhi Society alone and 12% in the WRDS alone. 21% of re- spondents were members of the RDS in their village. CBOs are a potential partner for the IPs and any development partner. In the focus group discussions CBO members demonstrated great enthusiasm to work in development pro- jects for their villages but lacked financial resources. Nevertheless they have undertaken or contributed to efforts in their villages such as repair of roads, clearing sites for drain- age and road construction and maintenance of public and community buildings. The focus group discussions revealed that CBOs were aware of the relevant government development partners but less of those belonging to the NGO sector. Where the latter had worked in a village it was at the NGO’s initiative. The evaluation team recommends that as part of a CBO capacity building component in their activities the IPs include: • mapping of potential NGOs and other sources of support and disseminating the re- sults to CBOs • providing training in proposal writing • preparing an inventory of community assets and ascertaining priority needs, ensuring that flanking measures are adapted to the needs expressed in each village.

RESULTS OF THE BASELINE STUDY 225 4.2 Needs Identified at Village Level The types of needs mentioned in our FGDs are the following. However, it should be not- ed that this represents a quick brainstorming exercise which can be improved upon by the IPs carrying out deeper consultations. This list is presented simply to show the wide range of needs identified in the five villages in which FGDs were held. • Training for pre-school teachers • Construction of paddy drying platforms • Toilets and safe drinking water facilities • Internal road renovation • Individual wells • Land ownership • Evening school classes for primary & secondary pupils • Dengue awareness • Renovation of culverts • Seeds and fertilisers for farmers • Clinic for pregnant and lactating mothers. • Skill development centre: language, vocational education and training (VET) • Small library • Renovation of tank for irrigation farming. • Renovate tanks in village to provide water in dry season • Irrigation • Houses The baseline survey provides more pointers to key improvements desired by villagers. When asked what physical infrastructure improvements needed to be made 34% of respondents, who were only allowed one answer each, answered “water supply and internal roads”. Results varied significantly between districts with Batticaloa respondents more concerned about internal and external roads (24%) than those in Kilinochchi (0%) and Mullaitivu (1%). It is possible that there are significant differences between villages in the same district too. As for social infrastructure needs health, education and child care proved the most pri- oritised at 28%, 22% and 22% respectively with all districts listing it as their first priority. Within health, 18% wanted a dispensary and 10% a “midwife medical centre”. Within education 19% wanted improvements to existing schools; only 3% gave pre-schools as their priority. Within the category of child care 19% of the 22% was accounted for by those who prioritised a day care centre or nursery. Other significant responses were for a playground (10%) and repairs to water reservoirs (ponds), also at 10%. 4.3 House Design 29% of all respondents in the baseline survey considered their house “permanent” rather than “temporary”. This will presumably be taken into account in the beneficiary selection process.

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 226 The most important improvement wanted from proposed housing programme was more space (36%), more security / safety (26%) and more privacy (18%). Interestingly, 10% gave “better relationship between family members” as the most important improvement wanted and one in twenty (5%) a “better relationship with neighbours”. This may reflect how temporary housing strains the social fabric of communities. Regarding sanitation facilities 57% of respondents stated that they had a toilet, all wa- ter-sealed pit latrines. However, approximately 60% of them needed repair. Unsurprisingly, no respondent had piped water in their houses. Although 22% had their own wells, over 60% depended on water from a well which was over 30 feet from the house. (That’s not far!) Rather more surprisingly, 48% of households had electricity connections. 60% of respondents felt “unsafe” or “very unsafe” in their current houses. 38% felt “fairly safe” and 2% “very safe”. Toilets have been one very significant improvement in the housing programme AUP- 2012. The Mid-Term Evaluation noted: In Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu districts (full and repair houses) detached toilets have often been built many metres away from the house (a paradox, taking into consideration the danger of snakes and overall insecurity, especially during the night). This choice is due to the perception, rooted in the traditional thinking mainly among rural Sri Lankans, particularly of the Tamils and especially in the northern districts, that a toilet in any form is “dirty” and hence needs to be de- tached and located at a distance from the main house ( 1 ) (only the urban elites are comfortable with internal toilets). However, during the observations many potential applicants of the future AUP-2014 said that detached toilets would be preferable for hygienic reasons - due to a scarcity of water. On the other hand, several potential AUP-2014 applicants were confused: regarding the toilet set-up in the envisaged new house, some said they would prefer an “internal toilet” (for security reasons, especially during the night), some preferred it “attached with ex- ternal access” (such as the AUP-2012 type design), for reasons of proximity but avoiding problems of hygienic and some also preferred “external and detached” for the reason given in the Mid-Term Evaluation. Three other interesting options were observed, as built within AUP-2012, and should be considered as lessons learnt within AUP-2014 (the first two positive, the third definitely negative). 1 A new house with an attached toilet should be introduced to new applicants through thorough capacity building sessions; people are now used to that and the presence of a Public Health Inspector would help in winning over people’s potential resistance

One which the team feels strongly should be taken up is the height of the spine wall as well as – consequently - that of the external walls. The reasoning for this is given in detail in the mid-term evaluation (pages 50-51). It is a technically reasonable and money-saving recommendation 1 . 4.6 Building Materials Focus group discussions revealed a high degree of conservatism regarding accept- able, alternative materials. There was an overwhelming preference for cement blocks for walling because of their perceived durability. Soil blocks were similarly rejected as their durability was questioned. They are seen as a temporary building material when a permanent house is what is wanted. The earth blocks may also be considered to reflect low status and backwardness when the newly returned refugees are looking for social advancement. The baseline survey confirms the a priori rejection of compressed earth blocks with a rejection rate of 100% in all three districts. However, this is probably be- cause of the nature of the survey instrument: it simply asks a question and does not allow discussion. In eight of the observations, on the other hand, beneficiaries were found to be open to the use of compressed stabilized earth block (CSEB) technology as long as they could count on the close support of project engineers, were instructed how to use it and received a full explanation of about its benefits and durability and so on. 4.6.1 Public sand mining There is a debate about the potential environmental impact of AUP-2014 regarding the use of river sand. Opinions about this were expressed during the workshop held in Kilin- ochchi (see next section), the programme’s Steering Committee meeting in Colombo and later in media and academic statements. It is the opinion of the evaluation team that this is not as dramatic an issue as sometimes portrayed 2 considering the total volume of sand expected to be used 3 , which is relatively small when compared with massive building initiatives across the country. It is the evaluators’ opinion that a housing programme such as AUP-2014 cannot serve as an experiment to develop new techniques and materials on a large scale. AUP-2014 proposes approximately 3,500 houses which will each use 12 cubic metres of sand which comes to a total for the entire programme of roughly 42,000 cubic metres of river sand for some 105,000 cubic metres of cast concrete. Considering a regular design plan (4x4 metre floor area and 4 metre height) and a plot surface of 1 hectare (10,000 square metres), the entire volume of concrete used in AUP-2014 (including sand) would be equivalent to what it takes to build just one 29-storey building.

There are some burning questions to be discussed at donor and IPs’ level such as: • Are beneficiaries expected to be limited in using non-renewable materials, by exploit- ing raw materials such as sand or Palmyra’s trees excessively? • Are they to be obliged to reduce sand mining, from both coastal and riverbed sites? 1 • Should they be made aware of coastal erosion and refrain from using raw materials because of that? The evaluation team do not think so. Beneficiaries, who spontaneously live in adequate harmony with their environment, should be made aware of environmental risks, but they should be given the right to build their “once in a lifetime house” without being subject to broader, major environmental constrains. A greater environmental burden should be placed on those with greater capacity to bear it, who are not the project beneficiaries. The AUP-2014 house should be a solid and traditional one, built according to agreed national and local technical rules, matching beneficiaries’ needs and beliefs, although sometimes contradicting certain reasonable technical approaches. EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 234 4.6.2 Alternative Building Materials Throughout the observations, it was noted that no potential AUP-2014 applicants were neither aware of nor interested in the appropriate techniques and materials which the programme is considering to use. They said that they would only be confident with alternative materials if they received a building engineer’s recommendation and then only if the house was sure to last longer than the present generation’s expected lifetime. The latter is important because housing is a non-replicable economic investment and is expected to serve a second family generation either through dowry or maintaining social status. This implies that significant effort will be required to ensure acceptability. The evaluators agree with the EU-Delegation’s stance whereby beneficiaries should not be exposed to experimentation with alternative materials. Hence, the importance that materials and construction techniques be consolidated and well established. Further, the underlying reason for promoting their use in this case should primarily be for local em- powerment (e.g. local income generation) rather than for global environmental reasons (e.g. vulnerable war-victims should not pay a higher cost to reduce CO2 emissions). Rammed earth is foreign to local construction traditions and it will be very difficult to mainstream its use, even for the 30 proposed houses. We consider the target set by HfH of 2/3 of houses being in CSEB overambitious and will need to be reviewed based on specialist feasibility studies on the viability of production, quality assurance in production and construction and in beneficiary acceptance. Acceptance of techniques such as CSEB and filler-slabs can only be tested through genuine efforts by the implementing partner in mainstreaming these alternatives. However, no beneficiary should be forced to adopt a material or technique they do not trust and hence the donor should both be demand- ing of the efforts but also show flexibility in adapting set targets to ensure appropriate materials are not imposed upon people. Advantage should be taken of the few houses already built with CSEB: other households should be invited to view the houses and discuss the construction process and benefits with the occupants. Through discussion converts might be made to the CSEB technology. This percentage target to be attained should be sufficient to ensure potential multiplier effects from the use of local materials (e.g. using CSEB would mean 100% of spending being made locally instead of approximately 80% ‘leaking’ out of the village when other materials are purchased) while minimising rejection by the community. Much will be determined by the viability of production too. The programme should target a sufficient market for potential micro-entrepreneurs to flourish. This operational structure would create more impact by managing sand procurement in bulk to the whole of AUP-2014 – not only the appropriate materials component – including housing and flanking measures activities. Nowadays, the GAs’ offices have a predetermined allowance (very limited, on a monthly basis) to mine and sell riverbed sand, leaving in turn a large amount of land vulnerable to illegal mining throughout the programme’s targeted districts. However, the evaluation team was told by public

RESULTS OF THE BASELINE STUDY 235 officers that more generous allowances of sand could potentially be permitted under certain circumstances, such as an obviously large housing programme like AUP-2014. Such permission would offer numerous benefits given that 1) GAs’ offices (in Batticaloa, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi districts) would have full supervision of the actual quantities and quality of materials mined in their respective districts, 2) private companies would enjoy transport to the housing scheme’s targeted villages at agreed rates and 3) beneficiaries and IPs would reduce time and money expenditures, assured of the quality and the source. Moreover, sand procurement in this way could be a powerful tool to stabilize raw materials prices, as the whole chain is well known by the public and transparent to all stakeholders. Carrying out procurement in this way would turn AUP-2014 into a partially assisted Owner Driven Approach (ODA). The argument for providing this assistance to what is supposed to be owner-driven is extensively argued in the MTE 1 and the evaluation team restates its earlier arguments here. If a “partially assisted ODA” approach were adopted it could include reviewing the pro- ject management plan to reduce the time taken in construction 2 and consequently the loss of income for those beneficiaries involved in building on a daily basis. 4.6.3 Workshop with implementing partners The evaluation team held a one-day workshop for implementing partners halfway through their fieldwork which was intended both as a capacity building exercise and an opportunity to verify the team’s findings to date. The list of the participants to the workshop is presented in Annex 3. The workshop was entitled Promoting Beneficiary Acceptance of Alternative Low-Cost and Environmentally-Friendly Construction Methods and Materials3 . Sri Lan- ka, (ii) gaining acceptance of appropriate low-cost methods and materials in AUP-2014 and (iii) building acceptability into AUP-2014. According to the feedback received from the workshop participants at the end of the day, it was well received and considered of value.
