RESULTS OF THE BASELINE STUDY 237 4.7 The construction process Regarding construction skills 22% of interviewees in Kilinochchi claimed that they had such skills (two-thirds of these were masons with the rest carpenters or electricians); the corresponding figure was 14% in Mullaitivu (all but one masons) and only 6% in Batticaloa (two masons and one electrician). If the IPs of AUP-2014 decide that these figures are not high enough it should be noted that the National Housing Development Authority (NHDA) has funds for hundreds of training courses and is ready to collaborate with the programme. However, it should be noted that the MTE found that very few of the beneficiaries’ family members used the construction skills they acquired during the AUP-2010 and AUP-2012 programmes. Almost all of them returned to traditional employment (mostly farming) and did not start a new career in construction. This may partly be because farming has a higher social status than being an unskilled construction labourer. In any case, it seems as if acquired construction skills do not necessarily translate into new employment. Al- though untested as a hypothesis, it may be that a higher level of training to semi-skilled proficiency will have more impact as status rises and the potential for higher incomes prove attractive. There are exceptional cases of (women) builders who have managed to complete their houses within the grant limits which many beneficiaries have claimed they could not do. It is useful for the AUP-2014 IPs to analyse these cases and whether their experience can be scaled up. One such case was reported in the MTE report 1 . Another was discovered during the baseline study. The case of “Devi” was presented in person to the workshop participants in Kilinochchi and explained to the Steering Committee held in Colombo. This beneficiary acted as a contractor for other households and somehow managed to build within time and budget. How precisely she did this needs research but includes op- timizing procurement, efficient use of labour and maximising beneficiaries’ responsibility. 4.8 Employment The household survey found that farming was the largest employment sector covering 31% of respondents with fishing and livestock rearing accounting for another 10%. The next largest group was unskilled labour at 13% with skilled labour at 11%. 12% of respondents claimed to be self-employed with another 7% owning small businesses. 7% of those interviewed were employed in public service and 8% of household heads were reported as working abroad. 99% of respondents claimed to be in full-time employment (i.e. working more than 50% of the working week) with 36% stating that they were able to save regularly. Batticaloa respondents were the highest in the latter category at 44%. 1 A woman (FHH – see Observation no. 30; in this current FTE Observation no. 01) saved some 50,000 LKR, by using sand for plastering from her plot and casting all blocks by herself

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 238 4.9 Borrowing and indebtedness The MTE and the Final Evaluation of AUP-2012 showed the serious consequences of pursuing housing construction without some discipline with expenditures. If it were prac- tical to use a household’s propensity to borrow as a criterion in the beneficiary selection process it would perhaps be possible to reduce indebtedness. However, past studies have shown that this would not be possible as almost all beneficiaries in AUP-2010 and AUP-2012 were inclined to borrow at some stage. This being said, families with high levels of debt prior to being selected in the programme need to be closely monitored and guided through difficult situations. In the Baseline Study for AUP-2014 a particular case was found to be heavily indebted, yet was in urgent need of housing assistance (Case Study 14). In the household survey for the final evaluation, when respondents were asked where they would obtain money in times of need or emergency 49% said they would only turn to a family member, friend, neighbour or a Samurdhi Society. Only 13% gave bank, pawn shop or money lender as their sole recourse though 38% included them as possible sources along with family, friends or neighbours. The survey of potential beneficiaries also found that there is a widespread practice of borrowing informally (Annex 2 – Table 2.2.40), which suggests that in any given difficult circumstance in the construction process there would be a tendency to reach out to local money lenders who would be quick to exploit the situation. As for saving practices, only a third of those surveyed responded positively (Table 2.2.39) Surprisingly, however, the non-participant observations found that 100% of potential applicants to AUP-2014 seemed to dislike the idea of acquiring debts for a new house. They seemed very prudent and conscious of the risk of entering into a vicious circle of borrowing (or pawning) and having to pay unmanageable rates of interest 1 . This contra- diction with the findings of the household survey is worth the IPs investigating further. 4.10 Dependency Almost all those interviewed during the observation process believe that externally fund- ed help for similar housing programmes will continue indefinitely beyond AUP-2014. One response to a question whether the non-selection of some villagers might affect social cohesion negatively was “No problem at all, since if we or others in the village do not qualify for this programme, we will keep waiting for the next one”. 1 In detail, they appeared shocked about past experiences (got indebted building their shacks after resettlement) and definitely not willing repeat similar experiences; “we do not care about luxury items, priorities are schooling our children and health”, many said

CONTINUITY BETWEEN AUP-2012 AND AUP-2014 239 5 Continuity between AUP-2012 and AUP-2014 In an interview the Batticaloa Government Agent Mrs. P.S.M. Charles pointed out the different approaches used by different housing programmes in her district. She referred to the very good implementation by UN-Habitat and other supporting agencies during AUP-2012 and contrasted it with the Indian Housing Project (as largely implemented by other agencies) during its first phase of implementation 1 (though this later improved). The GA advocated a much stronger focus on fully integrated implementation (housing, flanking measures, strong social components and community empowerment) and rec- ommended the IP for the coming AUP-2014 focus on the needier villages (which she estimated at some 35) where vulnerable people are still lacking help after resettlement. 5.1 Recommendations of the AUP-2012 Mid-Term Evaluation Many of the recommendations made by the evaluation team in the AUP-2012 mid-term evaluation are taken up in the design of AUP-2014. Examples of this are in the areas of: Beneficiary selection. However it should be pointed out that, with regard to the pro- posed scoring system for AUP-2014, a sense of complete unfairness was observed in Mullaitivu (Mullivaikai East village) where a group of potential applicants 2 to AUP-2014 explained their mistrust of selection systems. In the past they suffered because the IHP scoring system did not take into account both Divisional Secretary lists and the actually more vulnerable families. In particular, a group of widow-headed potential applicants 3 to AUP-2014 complained about the scoring system they experienced in the past and claimed they had not been scored appropriately, having also been disqualified from pre- vious housing programmes. Opinions found in the observations and the interview held with the Karachchi Divisional Secretary (Kilinochchi district) were in favour of a dedicated scoring system for special cases which would allow the inclusion of the most vulnerable applicants. • Livelihoods • Alternative building materials • Incremental housing • Creation of affordable sources of borrowing • Financial literacy training • Strengthening CBOs 1 She noted in detail “a lack of explanation from Technical Officers and bad quality materials” 2 See Observations nos.: 35, 36, 37 3 See Observations nos.: 12, 38, 39, 40

EVALUATION OF THE EU-FUNDED HOUSING RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAMMES IN SRI LANKA 240 The MTE of AUP-2012 included a chapter on “The Spread of Benefits”. It has been es- timated that when AUP-2014 has ended there will be a remaining 135,000 houses in need of repair or rebuilding. On average, if house costs are €4,000 for the AUP-2014 programme, the elimination of this deficit would require €540,000,000. This is many times more than what will have been spent in AUP-2010, AUP-2012 and the future AUP-2014. Therefore the evaluation team still believes and strongly recommends that for future programmes to reach their maximum breadth of housing production, costs need to be examined and cheaper options found. The team has already carried out an exer- cise 1 which sought to do this and believe these proposed alternative plans are still valid 2 . It is hoped that IPs within AUP-2014 will evaluate the proposed type plans (or any simi- lar), taking into account local religious beliefs and official regulations and revise the new proposed plans accordingly. Not all recommendations have been taken up and the team considers that they are worth reconsideration on the part Habitat for Humanity International as the implement- ing partner responsible for the housing component of the programme. These are in the areas of building materials and building standards (discussed above in sections 4.4. and 4.5.) However, it should be noted that the evaluation team’s terms of reference did not include assessment of the programme design and so these comments remain only as suggestions. 5.2 Institutional Memory The same point about the scope of the team’s terms of reference applies to its concerns about the possible loss of institutional memory which was accumulated by implementing partners of previous AUPs. This applies in particular to UN-Habitat which had the lead role in AUP-2010 and AUP-2012. The organisation accumulated an enormous amount of capacity and knowledge during these programmes and possessed many experienced and skilled staff. The evaluation team suggest that HfH and WVL look for a way to incor- porate as much of this capability as possible such as through the recruitment of UN-Hab- itat data experts, engineers, Technical and Social Officers who have become available in June 2016 on termination of AUP-2012. Where relevant the EUD could facilitate the transfer of data and network information from UN-Habitat to the new Implementing Partners. 1 See MTE, pages 26-34 2 If qualified, a single, widow household applicant in Kithul village (Batticaloa district) would just claim for a “one room house” (plus internal Kitchen, Toilet and veranda) as her dream-house (see Obs. No. 12). Such a condition, with only one vulnerable family member, should be considered within the proposed special cases dedicated scoring system, as it will increase the impact of the programme and the spread of benefits with relatively little disbursement of grants.
